finding: The rs10228066 variant was involved in a colocalization with fasting glucose and HbA1c traits, implicating it in regulatory pathways that connect with diabetes phenotypes through its interactions with beta-cell specific genes.
title: The three-dimensional chromatin structure of the major human pancreatic cell types reveals lineage-specific regulatory architecture of T2D risk

finding: This variant connected specifically in beta cells to the DGKB promoter and played a significant role in explaining the colocalization with fasting glucose and HbA1c, which were relevant traits in T2D.
title: The three-dimensional chromatin structure of the major human pancreatic cell types reveals lineage-specific regulatory architecture of T2D risk

finding: The rs2268382 variant was linked to the CPA4 gene specific to acinar cells, suggesting a novel implication of the exocrine pancreas in T2D pathogenesis, highlighting the complexity of the disease's genetic architecture.
title: The three-dimensional chromatin structure of the major human pancreatic cell types reveals lineage-specific regulatory architecture of T2D risk

finding: The SNP rs11977526 was linked to two traits in opposite directions, providing new insights into its association with blood pressure.
title: Multivariate Genomewide Association Analysis with IHT

finding: The AD-associated SNP rs1880949 localized within an active enhancer on chromosome 7 was linked to the promoter of ARPC1B, which is highly expressed in microglia. This finding designated ARPC1B as the predicted target gene for this SNP in the context of Alzheimer's disease.
title: SnapHiC-G: identifying long-range enhancer-promoter interactions from single-cell Hi-C data via a global background model

finding: SNP rs10241492 was associated with an enhancer-promoter interaction affecting the STAG3 gene’s promoter region in microglia, marking STAG3 as a potential target gene for this EDU-associated GWAS variant. This finding aligns with its identification as an eQTL from previous studies.
title: SnapHiC-G: identifying long-range enhancer-promoter interactions from single-cell Hi-C data via a global background model

finding: The SNP rs60600003 was implicated across multiple autoimmune diseases, including T1D, indicating potential shared regulatory pathways.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: The SNP rs3735025 was found to be associated with a co-localization event at the DGKI locus on chromosome 7, specifically within the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) samples. It was linked to alterations in RNA editing sites, notably Chr7_127067936. The association was significant with a p-value of 9.5 x 10^-9, indicating that this locus is implicated in schizophrenia risk. The analysis suggested a potential causal role of RNA editing at this locus in contributing to schizophrenia risk, based on the correlation with the derived editing quantitative trait loci (edQTLs) and schizophrenia genome-wide association study (GWAS) signals.
title: Dynamic landscape and genetic regulation of RNA editing in schizophrenia

finding: ABCB1 rs1128503 has been studied for its significant role in drug resistance, emphasizing its importance as a pharmacogenetic marker in colorectal cancer.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: ABCB1 rs1045642 was identified as a highly studied SNP that affects drug resistance in treatments, demonstrating its relevance in colorectal cancer pharmacogenomics.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: SNP rs1722141 was found to be genome-wide significant in both the UK Biobank (UKB) study and the EUR-specific meta-analysis of SHR.
title: Genetics of skeletal proportions in two different populations

finding: The rs111647033 variant in the ABCB5 gene was prioritized as damaging but the specific health implications in the context of the study were not provided.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing-based Characterization of Human Genome Variation and Mutation Burden in Botswana

finding: This SNP exhibited a cis effect on RARR2 and was identified as an eQTL linked to various genes. Its association with epigenomic marks indicated significant regulatory roles pertinent to obesity and metabolic disorders.
title: A large-scale multivariate pQTL study sheds light on the genetic architecture of obesity

finding: The study found that subjects with the ABCB1 rs10280101 A/A genotype had significantly higher prolactin concentrations compared to those carrying other alleles. This finding was linked to the drug aripiprazole (ARI) which does not typically induce hyperprolactinemia, indicating a potential role of genetic variability in prolactin level response to the drug.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: It was reported that participants with the ABCB1 rs12720067 C/C genotype had higher prolactin concentrations during aripiprazole treatment. This suggests that the genetic variant may influence prolactin levels in response to the medication.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: The ABCB1 rs11983225 T/T subjects exhibited significantly higher prolactin levels after aripiprazole treatment compared to carriers of other alleles. The findings suggested an association between this SNP and metabolic effects of the drug.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: The SNP rs6463843, which is flanking the NXPH1 gene, was identified as being associated with global and regional grey matter density loss in patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD). This finding was supported by a genome-wide association study (GWAS) analyzing neuroimaging phenotypes. The role of neurexophilin-1, encoded by NXPH1, in modulating synaptic plasticity and its localization to presynaptic terminals in neurons underscored the implications of this SNP in the context of synaptic and metabolic dysfunction linked to AD.
title: Single-cell sequencing of Entorhinal Cortex Reveals Wide-Spread Disruption of Neuropeptide Networks in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The IL6 gene polymorphism rs1800795 was indicated to influence muscle recovery and hypertrophy, with the G allele associated with lower muscle damage after exercise. The study highlighted a high presence of the G allele among athletes, suggesting it offered a competitive advantage in high-performance sports like gymnastics and swimming.
title: Genotypic and allelic distribution of the ACE, ACTN3, and IL6 genes in athletes of Artistic Gymnastics and Swimming in the department of Norte de Santander, Colombia

finding: The rs10954213 variant was associated with a higher prevalence of the short isoform of the IRF5 transcription factor. It was also linked to a higher risk of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and increased IRF5 expression due to the loss of AU-rich elements in the short transcript. These findings were supported by previous studies regarding the role of IRF5 in SLE-related pathways.
title: The length of the expressed 3’ UTR is an intermediate molecular phenotype linking genetic variants to complex diseases

finding: In females, the genotype at rs73170626 was associated with the expression of the TRBV30 gene during early puberty, while this effect was no longer present in late puberty. This gene is involved in T cell receptor function, highlighting the hormonal influences on immune gene expression during development.
title: Analysis of transcriptional changes in the immune system associated with pubertal development in a longitudinal cohort of children with asthma

finding: The SNP rs2071307 was linked with improved performance in elastin bearing tissues compared to the reference allele, highlighting its evolutionary advantages and its association with facial aging traits.
title: Biological insights from self-perceived facial aging data of the UKBB participants

finding: SNP rs55863875 in the ELN gene suggested an association with self-reported youthfulness, connecting elastin genetics to perceived facial aging. Its high linkage disequilibrium with rs2071307 was noted.
title: Biological insights from self-perceived facial aging data of the UKBB participants

finding: The SNP rs28763981 in the ELN gene was also found to be suggestively associated with self-reported youthfulness, reinforcing the connection between elastin and aging perceptions.
title: Biological insights from self-perceived facial aging data of the UKBB participants

finding: The SNP rs17855988, associated with cutis laxa, was noted to have suggestive links to self-reported youthfulness, therefore contributing to the discussion of elastin's role in aging.
title: Biological insights from self-perceived facial aging data of the UKBB participants

finding: CYP3A5*3 (rs776746) was found to have a high frequency of 0.8315 in African populations compared to non-African populations, highlighting its role in drug metabolism in African contexts.
title: The extent and impact of variation in ADME genes in sub-Saharan African populations

finding: The SNP rs2714700, located between MAGI2 and GNAI1 on chr7q21, was associated with nicotine dependence (ND) with a p-value of 2.3×10^-9 in a cross-ancestry meta-analysis. It was identified as a novel locus for ND that showed consistent associations across European (EUR) and African American (AA) populations. The rs2714700-T allele was associated with a reduced risk of severe ND compared to mild ND (odds ratio 0.96). This SNP demonstrated a significant association with the heaviness of smoking index (HSI) at p=0.014 in the UK Biobank. It was also a noted cis-eQTL for the MAGI2-AS3 transcript in the hippocampus, suggesting a potential regulatory role on gene expression related to ND.
title: Expanding the Genetic Architecture of Nicotine Dependence and its Shared Genetics with Multiple Traits: Findings from the Nicotine Dependence GenOmics (iNDiGO) Consortium

finding: The SNP rs1842993 was positively associated with the risk of cardioembolic stroke in the Slavic population, as reported by Shetova et al. in their 2012 study. This finding related to the genetic basis of ischemic stroke and contributed to understanding how specific genetic variants influence disease risk.
title: Object-Attribute Biclustering for Elimination of Missing Genotypes in Ischemic Stroke Genome-Wide Data

finding: The SNP rs7783715 was part of a network defined through multi-omics data, contributing additional nodes and edges, showing significant concordance with earlier findings and suggesting an extended influence in regulatory mechanisms.
title: Network reconstruction for trans acting genetic loci using multi-omics data and prior information

finding: The variant rs1031486 acted as a reQTL for the SEC61G gene in NK cells treated with LPS, where the A alleles were associated with higher gene expression following dexamethasone treatment. This gene was involved in the translocation of proteins into the endoplasmic reticulum and had implications in immune responses.
title: Genetic control of the dynamic transcriptional response to immune stimuli and glucocorticoids at single cell resolution

finding: The ACHE/rs1799806 variant was among the variants showing strong eQTL effects for several neighboring genes in brain regions and whole blood. It was noted as one of the most significant variants in association with AD.
title: Targeted Sequencing of Alzheimer’s Disease Genes in Gujarat Cohort

finding: The SNP rs1990620 in the TMEM106B gene was identified as a genome-wide significant variant that conferred protection from the inflammatory subtype of Late-Onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) in the ROSMAP cohort. This variant was replicated across all other studied cohorts at suggestive and significant levels, indicating its relevance in LOAD pathology.
title: Transcriptomic Stratification of Late-Onset Alzheimer’s Cases Reveals Novel Genetic Modifiers of Disease Pathology

finding: The study identified a significant association between the SNP rs1990622 in the gene TMEM106B and the risk of Major Depression (MD). This association was characterized as being strong, colocalized, and potentially causal, indicating that the variant had an independent effect on the gene expression relevant to MD. Given that rs1990622 was noted in the context of its relationship to TMEM106B, the findings suggested that previous research linking this marker to frontotemporal dementia could also implicate it in the genetic landscape of depression.
title: Delineating the Genetic Component of Gene Expression in Major Depression

finding: The SNP rs117738684 was associated with a lower abundance of Acinetobacter johnsonii (p=3.44×10^-9) and was linked to levels of blood testosterone, fasting sugar, and methionine, indicating a significant relationship between this genetic locus and metabolic traits.
title: Unraveling the impact of host genetics and factors on the urinary microbiome in a young population

finding: The SNP rs1799983 in the NOS3 gene was positively associated with incident dementia in elderly stroke survivors. This finding indicated that variations in the NOS3 gene could potentially influence neurological conditions following stroke, highlighting its role in vascular health and integrity.
title: Systems-wide analysis unravels the new roles of CCM signal complex (CSC)

finding: The SNP rs13246340 was associated with actionable deletions of CDKN2A/2B and kataegis observed in Anaplastic Thyroid Carcinoma, indicating its significance in the context of cancer genetics and therapy.
title: Katdetectr: An R/Bioconductor package utilizing unsupervised changepoint analysis for robust kataegis detection

finding: The SNP rs10224545, found in the PER4 gene, was identified as a novel locus associated with insulin resistance (HOMA-IR) and showed significant association with fasting insulin in the study, linking circadian rhythms to energy metabolism.
title: Genetics of fasting indices of glucose homeostasis using GWIS unravels tight relationships with inflammatory markers

finding: The potentially neuroprotective variant rs1990621 was indicated as present in TMEM106B, which could be relevant for studies on cellular vulnerability.
title: A reference induced pluripotent stem cell line for large-scale collaborative studies

finding: The SNP rs1805319 was identified in the context of a study examining the role of the MLH3 gene in the expansion mechanism of the glutaminase deficiency disorder GDPAG. The research highlighted that lesions in the MLH3 lines were confirmed by sequencing of the PCR product, enabling the unambiguous identification of the two alleles due to this known SNP. This finding was pertinent to understanding the genetic basis of repeat expansion in affected individuals.
title: All three MutL complexes are required for repeat expansion in a human stem cell model of CAG-repeat expansion mediated glutaminase deficiency

finding: The SNP rs1805324 was recognized as a tag for a distinguishable effect (7ABEM1) in the PMS2 gene, associated with increased somatic instability.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs63750123 was identified as a significant missense variant linked to increased somatic instability and corresponding clinical modification efforts (7ABEM4).
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs1805326 was elucidated as a significant factor in the PMS2 region, enhancing understanding of CAG expansion pathways.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs2345058 emerged as relevant in determining modifier effects in the PMS2 region, suggesting complexity in genetic balances affecting disease.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs3779109 did not indicate distinguishing effects subsequently during sequential analysis but zoned in on the dynamic genetic environment in Huntington's disease.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs12673868 pointed to distinguishable modifications within the PMS2 region, reflecting interplay among various genetic influences.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs75973354 marked another distinguishing effect in the PMS2 region, corroborating the diverse genetic contributors to Huntington's disease.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs2079819 was characterized as a significant factor in the PMS2 region, underlining the complex interactions surrounding disease modifiers.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: SNP rs17161332, associated with MAGI2, was mentioned as crucial in maintaining epithelial integrity and linked to inflammatory bowel diseases and acute GVHD.
title: Iterative feature selection method to discover predictive variables and interactions for high-dimensional transplant genomic data

finding: The SNP rs13246344 was associated with oncogenic signaling in the context of the PEAK3 pseudokinase, which was linked to poor prognosis in cancers like triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). This finding was acknowledged in the research by Ounoughene et al., highlighting the role of PEAK3 in SHED-dependent signaling relevant to tumor characteristics.
title: Feed-forward stimulation of CAMK2 by the oncogenic pseudokinase PEAK1 generates a therapeutically ‘actionable’ signalling axis in triple negative breast cancer

finding: The rs79451216 variant in the PSPH gene was identified as being frequently present in the Serbian population, showing two alleles R49W and R49G. The functional implications of these alleles involved disturbances in the PSPH protein functions, suggesting their role in decreasing glycine levels. This decrease in glycine was hypothesized to contribute to an increased susceptibility to cardiovascular diseases, which are prevalent in Serbia, correlating the SNP with a public health issue.
title: The first insight into the genetic structure of the population of modern Serbia

finding: The SNP rs342293 was identified as a GWAS SNP regulating the expression of the PIK3CG gene. This SNP disrupted a GATA site in the presence of the minor allele, which was associated with increased mean platelet volume (MPV) and decreased platelet reactivity. These findings contributed to understanding its impact on hematopoiesis and platelet biology.
title: Machine learning-based identification and cellular validation of Tropomyosin 1 as a genetic inhibitor of hematopoiesis

finding: The SNP rs1043595 was identified as being associated with cognitive traits. It was mentioned in the context of self-reported physical activity and its potential protective relationship against overall lung cancer, squamous cell carcinoma, and lung cancer in ever smokers.
title: Physical activity and risk of lung cancer: a two-sample Mendelian randomization study

finding: The SNP rs6968554, located in the 7q.21 locus, was significantly associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) according to the CARDIOGRAM+C4D GWAS (p=1e-4). It was identified as a cis-eQTL for the lncRNA AC003075.4, which is anti-sense to AHR in tibial artery tissues (p=2.5e-4). Furthermore, a negative feedback mechanism was suggested where knockdown of AC003075.4 decreased AHR expression and its overexpression increased AHR, supporting the regulation of AHR by TCF21 and AC003075.4 both linked to CAD phenotype.
title: The environment-sensing aryl-hydrocarbon receptor inhibits the chondrogenic fate of modulated smooth muscle cells in atherosclerotic lesions

finding: The intronic variant rs2190500 intersected the GRB10 gene in the Tu population and was associated with morningness, supporting its significance within adaptive traits.
title: Exploring adaptive introgression in modern human circadian rhythm genes

finding: The rs536864738 variant ablated a GFI1B repression site in K562 cells, revealing multiple activators capable of driving expression when this repression was disrupted.
title: Functional dissection of complex and molecular trait variants at single nucleotide resolution

finding: The variant rs2529369 functioned as a fine-mapped eQTL for CDHR3. Its effects were significantly influenced by the presence of SRY/SOX motifs, revealing sex-dependent allelic effects on expression.
title: Functional dissection of complex and molecular trait variants at single nucleotide resolution

finding: The SNP rs77126132 was positively identified in relation to glioma, particularly affecting white matter areas such as SCC and BCC.
title: Common genetic variation influencing human white matter microstructure

finding: The variant rs798510 was linked to anthropometric traits and significantly affected white matter microstructure within areas like SCR and PLIC.
title: Common genetic variation influencing human white matter microstructure

finding: The SNP rs2069832, located in the IL6 gene on 7p15.3, demonstrated a strong association with calcific aortic valve stenosis (CAVS) with a genome-wide significance of P=1.1×10^-8. This SNP was identified as a novel locus linked to inflammation and was associated with increased eosinophil count, systolic blood pressure, and carotid artery procedures, indicating its involvement in CAVS pathogenesis.
title: Genetic association analyses highlight IL6, ALPL, and NAV1 as three new susceptibility genes underlying calcific aortic valve stenosis

finding: Located near rs2069832 in the IL6 locus, this SNP achieved a strong PPC of 0.96 for causality. Its close proximity to a significant GWAS SNP and established effects linked to inflammation emphasizes its potential implications in CAVS.
title: Genetic association analyses highlight IL6, ALPL, and NAV1 as three new susceptibility genes underlying calcific aortic valve stenosis

finding: The coding variant p.Arg192His (rs2233580) in the PAX4 gene was uniquely and reproducibly associated with an increased risk for type 2 diabetes (T2D) in East Asian populations, exhibiting an odds ratio of approximately 1.75. This association was further supported by findings that 21.4% of individuals with early-onset T2D carried at least one rs2233580 allele. Additionally, carriers of the T allele (p.His192) demonstrated a dose-dependent earlier age of T2D onset and significantly lower C-peptide levels, suggesting impaired pancreatic beta cell function.
title: PAX4 loss of function alters human endocrine cell development and influences diabetes risk

finding: In the study, rs487813 was found to be a SNP under positive selection in the Punjabi population and was associated with CYP3A5 expression levels in lung tissue, indicating an impact on drug metabolism.
title: Signatures of co-evolution and co-regulation in the CYP3A and CYP4F genes in humans

finding: Analysis revealed that rs679320 was also under positive selection in the Punjabi population, affecting CYP3A5 expression in the lung, which is relevant for understanding population-specific response to drugs.
title: Signatures of co-evolution and co-regulation in the CYP3A and CYP4F genes in humans

finding: The SNP rs568859 was noted to be under positive selection in the Punjabi population, significantly linked to CYP3A5 expression in lung, demonstrating its role in metabolic functions of drugs.
title: Signatures of co-evolution and co-regulation in the CYP3A and CYP4F genes in humans

finding: The SNP rs10264272, associated with non-expression of CYP3A5, was found under positive selection in various African populations, highlighting its influence on drug metabolism.
title: Signatures of co-evolution and co-regulation in the CYP3A and CYP4F genes in humans

finding: Rs776746, known for causing low CYP3A5 expression, was shown to be under positive selection in African populations, impacting drug metabolism and response.
title: Signatures of co-evolution and co-regulation in the CYP3A and CYP4F genes in humans

finding: SNP rs4316067 was identified as the lead SNP associated with UDP N-acetyl-glucosamine levels, confirming the genetic basis for variations in this metabolite within the context of the NT5C3A gene.
title: Genome-wide metabolite quantitative trait loci analysis (mQTL) in red blood cells from volunteer blood donors

finding:
The SNP rs16879765 was identified as having a strong association with Dupuytren's disease (DD), with a genome-wide significance level of 
P_GWAS = 7.2 x 10^-41. It was located in an intron of the EPDR1 gene, which was shown to be significant in 10 different tissue panels, particularly in lung tissue (P_TWAS = 6.4 x 10^-31). This variant's effect correlated with decreased secretion of a nearby WNT-agonist, SFRP4, though functional evidence indicated EPDR1 as the disease-relevant gene. The product of EPDR1 was implicated in myofibroblast contractility, and all transcripts of EPDR1 were found in affected DD tissue. Additionally, knockdown of EPDR1 resulted in reduced contractility in fibroblast-populated collagen lattice assays, providing strong evidence of its role in the pathogenesis of DD.
title: Integrative analysis of Dupuytren’s disease identifies novel risk locus and reveals a shared genetic etiology with BMI

finding: Also identified was rs3958046 on chromosome 7, which was among the genome-wide significant variants linked to ADHD across the lifespan.
title: Shared genetic background between children and adults with attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The variant rs10246939 was observed in association with tea intake, showing both additive genetic effects.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: The splice donor variant rs274624 in GRM3 was linked to cereal intake (p=2.1×10⁻⁶, β=-0.011, 95% CI: -0.015 to -0.0064), suggesting its relevance to dietary habits.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs354033 was associated with multiple sclerosis and overlapped a GWAS haplotype block on chromosome 7. Novel splice junctions were validated with Illumina sequencing, and several exons were highly conserved, with most transcripts overlapping a CAGE peak at the 5' end.
title: Targeted, High-resolution RNA Sequencing of Non-coding Genomic Regions Associated with Neuropsychiatric Functions

finding: The SNP rs10248565, located in the HDAC9 gene, was identified as a novel genomic aberration biomarker specifically associated with lung adenocarcinoma in non-smoking women. This finding highlighted the potential role of this SNP in the context of cancer susceptibility in a specific demographic.
title: Association Tests Using Copy Number Profile Curves (CONCUR) Enhances Power in Rare Copy Number Variant Analysis

finding: The SNP rs10081293 was linked to the tracking of structural and physiological phenology in Mediterranean ecosystems through the use of near-infrared digital photography, suggesting its involvement in seasonal leaf dynamics.
title: A general model for the seasonal to decadal dynamics of leaf area

finding: The SNP rs13073 was studied with respect to the gene PEG10. Similar to rs1056893, Ornaments outperformed WASP by accurately estimating allele-specific expression at the transcript level, thus showcasing its effectiveness in analyzing allelic read counts.
title: Ornaments for Accurate and Efficient Allele-Specific Expression Estimation with Bias Correction

finding: Lead variant rs10260419, while not reaching genome-wide significance, was associated with epithelial ovarian cancer risk within specific populations. Its relevance was highlighted in the context of the gene THSD7A.
title: Pleiotropy-guided transcriptome imputation from normal and tumor tissues identifies new candidate susceptibility genes for breast and ovarian cancer

finding: The SNP rs3801387, located near the WNT16 gene, was found to be significantly associated with bone mineral density (BMD). This association was observed even after accounting for genetic linkage, supporting its role as an independent signal at the CPED1-WNT16 locus. The findings suggested that variants near WNT16 influence bone-related traits through its expression and functional role in bone morphogenesis and mass.
title: wnt16 regulates spine and muscle morphogenesis through parallel signals from notochord and dermomyotome

finding: The SNP rs13245690, located near the CPED1 gene, was also independently associated with BMD. Similar to rs3801387, the association was significant, indicating that it could act on different regulatory elements within the CPED1-WNT16 locus. This suggests that both variants affect distinct pathways or mechanisms influencing bone morphology and density.
title: wnt16 regulates spine and muscle morphogenesis through parallel signals from notochord and dermomyotome

finding: The SNP rs17249 was identified as introducing a stop codon in the TRBV10-1 gene, validating its presence in cases showing hemizygous loss of expression and essential for understanding the causes of TCR diversity.
title: Archaic humans have contributed to large-scale variation in modern human T cell receptor genes

finding: As a stop codon variant in the TRBV6-8 gene, rs361451 was associated with cases showing loss of expression, helping illustrate the effect of similar SNPs on TCR gene functionality.
title: Archaic humans have contributed to large-scale variation in modern human T cell receptor genes

finding: This SNP variant was identified in association with TRBV30, contributing to expression patterns observed in African populations, where it was found at almost 40% frequency, indicating its relevance to TCR diversity.
title: Archaic humans have contributed to large-scale variation in modern human T cell receptor genes

finding: The SNP was part of the observed haplotypes in TRBV30, contributing to the understanding of genetic architecture in TCR variations among populations, especially in Africans.
title: Archaic humans have contributed to large-scale variation in modern human T cell receptor genes

finding: This SNP appeared with rs361463 as part of the TRBV30 haplotype, indicating its association with TCR gene expression in populations showing diverse TCR repertoires.
title: Archaic humans have contributed to large-scale variation in modern human T cell receptor genes

finding: This SNP variant, appearing alongside rs361462 and rs361463 in TRBV30, contributed to understanding the genetic basis of TCR diversity and how particular alleles can be population-specific.
title: Archaic humans have contributed to large-scale variation in modern human T cell receptor genes

finding: The intronic variant rs2075672 was found to lie in a peak primarily accessible in Ts21 haematopoietic stem cells (HSCs), with a significance value of P = 5.0×10^-3. Its accessibility correlated with the expression of TFR2, a gene implicated in the regulation of erythropoiesis, evidenced by a P value of 2.0×10^-4. In the single-cell RNA sequencing dataset, TFR2 expression was significantly higher in Ts21 HSCs compared to disomic HSCs (P = 1.8×10^-3), and even higher in cycling Ts21 HSCs (P = 3.5×10^-31), indicating that the variant is associated with increased TFR2 expression, relevant to the haematological profile of Down's Syndrome.
title: Single-cell multi-omics map of human foetal blood in Down’s Syndrome

finding: SNP rs631653 was associated with greater thickness in the perisylvian cortex for anxiety (ANX), which emphasizes its involvement in cortical variations.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs6461049 correlated with lower SA and CT in the primary cortex for both BD and SCZ, setting it apart as a significant variant.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs871925 showed associations with lower SA and CT in the primary cortex related to both BD and SCZ, emphasizing its genetic relevance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs10261780 showed associations with the thickness of sensorimotor cortex for ADHD, reflecting its role in cortical structure.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs66571810 indicated involvement with the thickness of the sensorimotor cortex for ADHD, outlining its genetic implications.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs17137124 was jointly linked to thickness in the sensorimotor cortex for ADHD, supporting its relevance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: The SNP rs12113244 was examined in the context of the lactate's role in the TME according to Pérez-Tomás et al. in 2020. Their findings suggested that genetic factors at this locus could influence the metabolic microenvironment, which is critical for cancer progression and treatment responses.
title: From tumor microenvironment to immuno-therapeutic outcomes for solid tumors: A systems theoretic approach

finding: The SNP rs13239597 was identified as a significant genetic variant associated with an increased risk for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and Systemic Sclerosis (SSc). This SNP was located in a putative enhancer region in the promoter of TNPO3, approximately 118kb from its distal target gene IRF5. Functional analyses demonstrated that the rs13239597-A allele increased IRF5 expression and enhanced chromatin interactions between rs13239597 and the IRF5 promoter, suggesting its role as an allele-specific enhancer. The connection between this SNP and IRF5 was further corroborated by eQTL studies that highlighted the association of rs13239597-A with elevated IRF5 expression across multiple datasets, emphasizing its significance in autoimmune disease pathogenesis.
title: An allele-specific functional SNP associated with two autoimmune diseases modulates IRF5 expression by long-range chromatin loop formation

finding: SNP rs1544474 was implicated in the regulation of LAMB1 by altering transcription factor binding in an enhancer region, which decreased LAMB1 expression significantly in adult Schwann cells. This SNP served as a regulatory modulator within transcription networks.
title: NetREm: Network Regression Embeddings reveal cell-type transcription factor coordination for gene regulation

finding: The SNP rs13236136 was associated with promising antigens for targeted immunotherapy in multiple myeloma, as highlighted in the work by Cho et al. (2021). This finding was critical because it illustrated the potential genetic influence on the effectiveness of immunotherapy in treating multiple myeloma.
title: Immune-mediated tumor control in the 5TGM1 transfer model of multiple myeloma

finding: The co-eQTLs related to the SNP rs7806458 were linked to TMEM176A and TMEM176B in monocytes. These co-eQTLs suggested a connection between rs7806458 and multiple sclerosis (MS), highlighting pathways related to blood coagulation that may be disturbed in MS, thus providing mechanistic insights into the disease.
title: Identification of genetic variants that impact gene co-expression relationships using large-scale single-cell data

finding: The SNP rs1569055 was associated with increased COVID-19 severity in patients. It was identified approximately 230kb downstream of the TRIM4 promoter, which is involved in activating type I interferon signaling. Proximity proteomics data indicated that TRIM4 was significantly associated with the SARS-CoV-2 M protein, suggesting that individuals carrying this SNP might express lower levels of TRIM4. Consequently, the proximity of TRIM4 to the SARS-CoV-2 M protein potentially diminishes TRIM4 functionality, leading to reduced innate immune signaling and increased susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 related pathogenesis.
title: The proximal proteome of 17 SARS-CoV-2 proteins links to disrupted antiviral signaling and host translation

finding: The finding indicated that a mutation occurred at position 1, changing the Methionine residue to Arginine. This mutation was identified within the signal peptide of the PRSS1 protein. The properties of the new Arginine residue differed significantly from those of the original Methionine residue. The change was expected to disrupt the recognition of the signal peptide, potentially leading to a loss of hydrophobic interactions, which could impair the protein's function.
title: Novel mutations within PRSS1 Gene that could potentially cause hereditary pancreatitis: Using Comprehensive in silico Approach

finding: This SNP involved a mutation at position 4, where Leucine was changed to Proline. Located within the signal peptide, the mutation altered the properties of the peptide. The Proline residue was smaller and more hydrophobic than the original Leucine residue, which might interfere with the peptide's recognition necessary for proper protein maturation and functionality. The modification in size and hydrophobicity suggested that there could be a loss of essential interactions required for the correct processing of the protein.
title: Novel mutations within PRSS1 Gene that could potentially cause hereditary pancreatitis: Using Comprehensive in silico Approach

finding: Found within the CAV1-AF1 region, the rs3807989 variant exhibited significant enhancer activity in transgenic embryos, activating gene expression of CAV1 and other nearby genes. This proved its significance as a positive regulatory element linked to electrical function in cardiomyocytes.
title: Systematic in vivo interrogation identifies novel enhancers and silencers associated to Atrial Fibrillation

finding: The SNP rs4410790 in the AHR gene showed strong association with tea drinking behaviors and influenced the pooled effect estimate for the causal relationship with PD. The OR decreased when this SNP was omitted, indicating its importance in the overall assessment.
title: The Parkinson’s Disease Mendelian Randomization Research Portal

finding: This SNP was found in the COG5 gene and showed significant associations with LDL, contributing to the link between coronary artery disease and lipid traits.
title: A method to map and interpret pleiotropic loci using summary statistics of multiple traits

finding: The missense variant rs1859788-A in the PILRA locus was both a positive and original finding. It was identified in high linkage disequilibrium (R^2=0.85) with the tagging variant and was previously shown to alter the ligand binding affinity of PILRA, supporting its role in altering AD risk.
title: Integration of Alzheimer’s disease genetics and myeloid cell genomics identifies novel causal variants, regulatory elements, genes and pathways

finding: The SNP rs1990620 was associated with a reduced excitatory neuron fraction, showing the strongest association (P=6.4e-09) in the TMEM106B locus. This association indicated a significant role in the context of frontotemporal lobar degeneration with TDP-43 inclusions (FTLD-TDP) and cognitive decline independent of Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology. The allele linked to decreased neuronal fraction also corresponded to increased FTLD-TDP risk and lowered cognition in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
title: Single-cell deconvolution of 3,000 post-mortem brain samples for eQTL and GWAS dissection in mental disorders

finding: The SNP rs4721064 was associated with inhibitory neurons within the TMEM106B locus. This association demonstrated independence and additive effects with those of rs1990620, with a statistical significance of p=1.69e-06, indicating its relevance in neuron type-specific genetic mechanisms.
title: Single-cell deconvolution of 3,000 post-mortem brain samples for eQTL and GWAS dissection in mental disorders

finding: At the SEMA3C gene, rs917191 was identified as a lead variant connected to WHRadjBMI and shown to lead to increased expression of the SEMA3C gene, suggesting its vital role in adipose tissue function.
title: Adipose tissue eQTL meta-analysis reveals the contribution of allelic heterogeneity to gene expression regulation and cardiometabolic traits

finding: The proxy variant rs12537553 was explored for its transcriptional activity regarding the SEMA3C gene; however, it did not show significant transcriptional differences compared to rs917191, indicating a secondary role.
title: Adipose tissue eQTL meta-analysis reveals the contribution of allelic heterogeneity to gene expression regulation and cardiometabolic traits

finding: The mutation causing GA3 in the Amish (rs137852860) exhibited an allele frequency of 9.3% in the Amish population and 0.8% in non-Finnish Europeans. Its presence among homozygous individuals in a population-based database was considered evidence that it is not disease-causing, leading to the consensus that SUGCT deficiency does not result in a clinically significant disease.
title: Glutaric aciduria type 3 is a naturally occurring biochemical trait in inbred mice of 129 substrains

finding: The variant rs10229453 (T/C) was associated with all three active promoters of MUC12-AS1 but exhibited opposite effects: prmtr.99696 (p = 2.25 x 10^-56, beta = -0.95), prmtr.99698 (p = 5.02 x 10^-20, beta = 0.60), and prmtr.99699 (p = 4.02 x 10^-9, beta = 0.40). It was not linked to the total expression level of the gene (p = 0.21), indicating a nuanced role in the regulation of promoter activity.
title: Mapping of promoter usage QTL using RNA-seq data reveals their contributions to complex traits

finding: The SNP rs12113227 was associated with TLR3 functionality in the context of cancer therapy resistance. It was highlighted in the study by Muresan et al., indicating that variations at this locus might influence tumor cell responses to treatments targeting Toll-like receptors.
title: Metadichol an agonist/antagonist that expresses the Toll Like Receptor family in various Cancer Cell Lines and its potential Impact on Cancer Treatment

finding: The SNP rs7806550 served as a significant rtQTL and eQTL for the genes ITGB8 and MACC1, which are associated with cellular interactions and growth motility, respectively. The ancestral allele frequency for rs7806550 was found to be highest in African populations and much lower in out-of-Africa populations, indicating a pattern of selection and frequency change of the derived allele in the human lineage. This SNP was linked to earlier replication timing in humans compared to chimpanzees and was predicted to alter transcription factor binding sites, influencing chromatin accessibility and gene expression.
title: The evolution of the human DNA replication timing program

finding: The SNP rs118079376 at the AMPH locus achieved a p-value of 2.64 × 10-10, thus identifying it as one of the additional novel loci uncovered in the study.
title: Scalable probabilistic PCA for large-scale genetic variation data

finding: The finding revealed that rs3807306 was associated with IBD, located near the IRF5 gene, and was part of the mQTLs involved in the DNA methylation changes reported in the context of IBD.
title: The DNA Methylome of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) reflects intrinsic and extrinsic factors in intestinal epithelial cells

finding: The SNP rs782509254 was identified as a rare polymorphism in human tropoelastin that was predicted to significantly increase the probability of the acceptor site for exon 22. This change was expected to increase the likelihood of including domain 22, a large hydrophobic domain, between domains 21 and 23, which are cross-linking domains in the protein. In vitro investigations indicated that this inclusion might significantly affect the functional properties of elastin.
title: Evolutionary Constraints on Positional Sequence, Collective Properties and Sequence Style of Tropoelastin Dictated by Fundamental Requirements for Formation and Function of the Extracellular Elastic Matrix

finding: The variant V238A, corresponding to rs542523237, was noted to have significant effects on the structure of CYP3A5, particularly due to its position on the F/G loop segment. It was found to influence the allostery of the protein and affect the pocket volume and binding of the drug ritonavir, indicating its relevance in drug response.
title: Single nucleotide polymorphism induces divergent dynamic patterns in CYP3A5: a microsecond scale biomolecular simulation of variants identified in Sub-Saharan African populations

finding: The SNP rs12666575 was identified as a genetic polymorphism in the mad1l1 gene, which had been associated with schizophrenia susceptibility in a Chinese population. This finding was significant as it contributed to the understanding of genetic factors involved in mental health disorders, providing insights into how variations at this locus may relate to conditions such as adolescent depression.
title: Differentially methylated regions and methylation QTLs for teen depression and early puberty in the Fragile Families Child Wellbeing Study

finding: The SNP rs17345286 was associated with levels of asparagine, demonstrating a significant genetic effect relevant to metabolism.
title: Cross-platform genetic discovery of small molecule products of metabolism and application to clinical outcomes

finding: This variant was in high linkage disequilibrium with rs17345286 and involved in asparagine synthesis, linking it to metabolic processes.
title: Cross-platform genetic discovery of small molecule products of metabolism and application to clinical outcomes

finding: The SNP rs972284 revealed significant genotype-by-sex interactions associated with KLF14, emphasizing its role in sex-specific genetic influences in obesity.
title: Identifying latent genetic interactions in genome-wide association studies using multiple traits

finding: The SNP rs13225701 was associated with the endocannabinoid system's role as a pharmacological target for new cancer therapies, indicating its relevance in cancer treatment strategies.
title: The Two-Step Cell Death Induction by the New 2-Arachidonoyl Glycerol Analog and its Modulation by Lysophosphatidylinositol in Human Breast Cancer Cells

finding: The SNP rs723527 was identified within a conserved enhancer element (CE5) in the intronic region of the EGFR gene. It was associated with increased glioblastoma risk and was found to play a significant role in regulating EGFR expression. Perturbation of this regulatory enhancer using CRISPR methods resulted in reduced EGFR expression, decreased proliferative and invasive capacity of glioblastoma cells, and increased sensitivity to temozolomide treatment.
title: Epigenomic perturbation of novel EGFR enhancers reduces the proliferative and invasive capacity of glioblastoma and increases sensitivity to temozolomide

finding: This SNP was detected as a potential outlier related to total breast cancer, indicating a need for further investigation concerning its influence.
title: Coffee consumption and risk of breast cancer: a Mendelian Randomization study

finding: The nsSNP rs587783625, represented as V621M, was identified as significantly affecting the structure of EZH2. This variant was associated with Weaver Syndrome and was shown to have a deleterious impact on the protein's function when analyzed alongside its interaction with the H3K27me0 peptide.
title: Structural dynamics of non-synonymous SNPs of histone methyltransferase EZH2 involved in Weaver Syndrome

finding: The nsSNP rs397515547, known as A677T, demonstrated lower binding energy with the H3K27me0 peptide due to structural denaturation, indicating a significant change in EZH2 functionality. This variant was also crucial to the study of Weaver Syndrome.
title: Structural dynamics of non-synonymous SNPs of histone methyltransferase EZH2 involved in Weaver Syndrome

finding: The nsSNP rs587783626, indicated as R679C, was analyzed as part of the study. Although its specific impact was not highlighted as significantly changing binding affinity or structure compared to other variants, it was included as one of the key nsSNPs relevant to Weaver Syndrome pathology.
title: Structural dynamics of non-synonymous SNPs of histone methyltransferase EZH2 involved in Weaver Syndrome

finding: The nsSNP rs193921147, denoted as H689Y, was found to exhibit lower binding energy with the H3K27me0 peptide, attributed to structural changes within the protein. This finding emphasized H689Y's deleterious effects on EZH2 function, relating it tightly to the molecular basis of Weaver Syndrome.
title: Structural dynamics of non-synonymous SNPs of histone methyltransferase EZH2 involved in Weaver Syndrome

finding: Similarly, rs73729083 at the CREB3L2 locus showed association with total cholesterol (TC), while earlier studies reported its connection with LDL-C, demonstrating the variant's importance in cholesterol metabolism.
title: Whole genome sequence analysis of blood lipid levels in >66,000 individuals

finding: The SNP rs60600003 was found to be the lead variant within the caQTL peak associated with the ELMO1 locus. It showed significant association with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), and multiple sclerosis (MS) and was linked to chromatin accessibility and expression of ELMO1 in lymphoblastoid cell lines (LCLs).
title: Chromatin accessibility variation provides insights into missing regulation underlying immune-mediated diseases

finding: The SNP rs1990621 was associated with protection against frontotemporal dementia (FTLD) and linked to an increased neuronal proportion. It contributed to neuroprotection in the context of tau-associated cognitive decline, neurodegeneration, and paralysis. This finding highlighted the role of TMEM106B and its coding variant in safeguarding against tau aggregation, thereby suggesting its importance in age-associated dementias.
title: TMEM106B coding variant is protective and deletion detrimental in a mouse model of tauopathy

finding: Located on Chromosome 3, SNP rs205735 demonstrated a strong association with a high heritability trait (H2 = 0.94) related to another trait analyzed. It was consistently identified across the two planting locations, further confirming its significant role in climate adaptability.
title: Identification and analysis of genomic regions influencing leaf morpho-physiological traits related to stress responses in Dioscorea alata

finding: The SNP rs12113142 was associated with determining the functional Notch signaling pathway activity in human cancer. This finding was part of a larger study highlighted in a 2020 publication that focused on measuring pathway activities in various disease states, including cancer, showcasing its importance in understanding immune responses.
title: Measuring host immune response status by simultaneous quantitative measurement of activity of signal transduction pathways that coordinate functional activity of immune cells from innate and adaptive immune system

finding: The rs3918226 SNP was identified at the NOS3 locus, correlating with CAD risk specifically within endothelial peaks.
title: Cell-specific chromatin landscape of human coronary artery resolves regulatory mechanisms of disease risk

finding: The SNP rs4464850 was associated with the expression of the gene <italic>PRKAR1B</italic>. This association was found when comparing TB patients with healthy controls while adjusting for Bantu-speaking African ancestry.
title: cis-eQTL mapping of TB-T2D comorbidity elucidates the involvement of African ancestry in TB susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs117842122 was linked to the expression of <italic>PRKAR1B</italic> in the comparison of TB-T2D patients with T2D patients, while adjusting for Khoe-San ancestry. This suggests a role in TB progression within this patient group.
title: cis-eQTL mapping of TB-T2D comorbidity elucidates the involvement of African ancestry in TB susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs12531478 was linked to the expression of <italic>FAM20C</italic> in the analysis which adjusted for Khoe-San ancestry, highlighting its eQTL significance.
title: cis-eQTL mapping of TB-T2D comorbidity elucidates the involvement of African ancestry in TB susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs776746 encodes the nonfunctional CYP3A5*3 allele, contributing to substantial inter-racial variation in drug metabolism. The C allele frequency was low in African populations but high in Europeans, whereas the T allele had the opposite trend. This SNP was associated with several drug responses, including decreased doses of Tacrolimus in kidney transplantation, increased metabolism of amlodipine, and varied responses to Atorvastatin and cyclosporine. The favored mutation T was recognized for its significant implications in drug efficacy and safety in the European population IBS.
title: PopTradeOff: a database for exploring population-specific trade-offs between adaptive evolution, disease susceptibility, and drug responsiveness

finding: The SNP rs75401036, located on chromosome 7, was identified as a genome-wide significant pQTL for MUC5AC. This variant was linked with higher concentrations of MUC5AC in the sputum of COPD patients, indicating its relevance to mucus hypersecretion associated with COPD phenotypes.
title: Genetic Regulators of Sputum Mucin Concentration and Their Associations with COPD Phenotypes

finding: A novel variant rs116644203 located within the ZNF282 locus was discovered in one individual among the AD cases. This variant was part of a significant large region of homozygosity (14.9 Mb), suggesting its potential relevance to the recessive inheritance patterns observed in AD.
title: Autosomal Recessive Alzheimer’s disease (arAD): homozygosity mapping of genomic regions containing arAD loci

finding: The SNP rs12113244 was associated with lactate levels in the tumor microenvironment, contributing to cancer progression and treatment strategies. This association was significant as it highlighted how metabolic regulation through this SNP could influence lactate dehydrogenase activity and subsequently affect glycolytic flux and oxidative phosphorylation in cancer cells.
title: Elucidating the kinetic and thermodynamic insight into regulation of glycolysis by lactate dehydrogenase and its impact on tricarboxylic acid cycle and oxidative phosphorylation in cancer cells

finding: This SNP was ranked in the top 25 priority SNPs for Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson disease, and multiple sclerosis, suggesting its significant implication across these nervous system diseases.
title: Genetic variability in pathways associates with pesticide-induced nervous system disease in the United States

finding: The rs587777472 variant was a missense variant altering the amino acid from tryptophan to cysteine in the conserved OB domain of the POT1 protein. This variant was found in the 5-case family UF20 and ranked at the 37th position (99.96 percentile) in the combined ranked list of variants, indicating its significance in melanoma susceptibility.
title: A Weights-based variant ranking pipeline for familial complex disorders

finding: The rs587777473 variant was a stop gain variant found in the 6-case family AF1. It was ranked at the 2955th position (96.75 percentile) in the combined variant list, also deemed damaging by predictive tools.
title: A Weights-based variant ranking pipeline for familial complex disorders

finding: The SNP rs10081293 was associated with structural and physiological changes in Mediterranean tree-grass ecosystems as reported in the study by Luo et al. (2018). The research utilized near-infrared digital photography to monitor these changes, suggesting that rs10081293 could provide important insights into phenological dynamics involving phenotypic traits related to root and above-ground vegetation interactions.
title: Replicate Sub-Daily Minirhizotron Sampling, Data and Interpretation for Root Dynamics Studies

finding: The SNP rs13225716 was examined in the context of combining radiotherapy with targeted therapy or immunotherapy in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, demonstrating its potential impact on treatment outcomes.
title: Manipulating the EphB4-ephrinB2 axis to reduce metastasis in HNSCC

finding: This SNP was found to have prognostic significance in recurrent laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma, highlighting its potential impact on cancer outcomes.
title: SearcHPV: a novel approach to identify and assemble human papillomavirus-host genomic integration events in cancer

finding: The study found that the rs11556924-T allele in the ZC3HC1 gene was associated with a reduced risk of coronary artery disease (CAD), showing a 4.9% to 7.0% risk reduction per allele. In contrast, this same SNP was linked to an increased risk of carotid intima-media thickness (IMT) in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis, illustrating its biphasic role in cardiovascular phenotypes.
title: Deficiency of ZC3HC1 modulates vascular smooth muscle cell phenotype and increases neointima formation

finding: The MS rs185087 SNP was associated with an increased risk of coronary artery disease (CAD), highlighting its potential role in cardiovascular health.
title: Screening key genes and signaling pathways in COVID-19 infection and its associated complications by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: The TMEM106B SNP rs3173615 was associated with a protective role in chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE). This variant was specifically noted to correlate with lowered neuroinflammatory responses and may influence disease severity, suggesting that individuals homozygous for the non-protective C allele represent a risk group for CTE pathology. This interpretation arose from gene expression and differential analysis comparing pathological and control samples.
title: Inflammation and neuronal gene expression changes differ in early vs late chronic traumatic encephalopathy brain

finding: The SNP rs12111903 was associated with insect mass estimation using radar cross section parameters and a support vector regression algorithm, as reported in the study by Hu et al. (2020). The research indicated that this SNP contributed to the ability to estimate body mass effectively, suggesting its relevance in the context of insect size analysis.
title: WOLO: Wilson Only Looks Once – Estimating ant body mass from reference-free images using deep convolutional neural networks

finding: This SNP (rs11772580) was associated with the gene PILRB across RPE1 and RPE2, which have been associated with geographic atrophy.
title: Transcriptomic and proteomic retinal pigment epithelium signatures of age-related macular degeneration

finding: Associated with PILRB in RPE3, the SNP rs2404976 was implicated in the genetic network associated with geographic atrophy.
title: Transcriptomic and proteomic retinal pigment epithelium signatures of age-related macular degeneration

finding: The SNP rs13235909 was identified within a novel prognostic biomarker panel for early-stage colon carcinoma as reported by Azcue et al. in 2021. This study suggested that the presence of the SNP could serve as a predictive marker for therapeutic efficacy related to the differentiation therapy approach, particularly in the context of colorectal cancers (CRCs) where CDX2 expression is critical. The findings pointed towards a potential reduction in mortality and recurrence rates by approximately 50%, aligning with the expectations set in the broader research context of differentiation therapy targeting CRC cancer stem cells.
title: Network-guided Therapeutics to Differentiate Colorectal Cancer Stem Cells

finding: The variant rs4307239 showed a significant association with BMI in individuals of European ancestry, linked to the NPY gene. Its genetic association was characterized by a very low p-value (p=1 × 10⁻¹¹), reinforcing previous findings of NPY's role in obesity.
title: A survey of proteomic variation across two ethnic groups in Nigeria and its relationship to obesity risk

finding: The SNP rs143118835 on chromosome 7 was identified to be associated with the white matter tract forceps major.
title: Genetic signatures of human brain structure: A comparison between GWAS and relatedness-based regression

finding: This SNP was connected to insulin-like growth factor-1 levels in Europeans, showcasing its importance in metabolic traits (beta=0.211, p=6.01×10^-85).
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: This SNP was associated with contracture of palmar fascia in Europeans, indicating its involvement in musculoskeletal traits (beta=0.678, p=2.58×10^-46).
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: This SNP demonstrated relevance in metabolic factor associations.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: This SNP showed connections to serum levels of metabolic substances.
title: The impact of evolutionary processes in shaping the genetics of complex traits in East Asia and Europe: a specific contribution from Denisovan and Neanderthal introgression

finding: The SNP rs2268574 in the Glucokinase gene was associated with GDM. This association illustrated the genetic mechanisms that could underlie the development of gestational diabetes.
title: Genome-Wide Polygenic Risk Scores and Prediction of Gestational Diabetes in South Asian Women

finding: Found in an enhancer region associated with multiple myeloma and AL amyloidosis, rs4487645 disrupted a PAX5 TF binding motif, leading to hypomethylation of the REF allele, which correlated strongly with ASM at the locus.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: This SNP was identified as being associated with an array of steroid hormone metabolites, demonstrating the complex genetic underpinnings relevant to metabolic diversity.
title: Genome-microbiome interplay provides insight into the determinants of the human blood metabolome

finding: This SNP was associated with the same set of 11 steroid hormone metabolites along with rs148982377, indicating shared genetic influence in metabolic pathways.
title: Genome-microbiome interplay provides insight into the determinants of the human blood metabolome

finding: This SNP in the CPS1 gene was shown to interact with gut microbiome factors affecting homoarginine levels, connecting it to cardiovascular disease risk.
title: Genome-microbiome interplay provides insight into the determinants of the human blood metabolome

finding: The SNP rs3173615 was identified as a protective allele which, in homozygous form, completely shielded carriers of the autosomal dominant progranulin (GRN) mutation from developing frontotemporal dementia (FTD). This finding indicated that TMEM106B plays a significant role in modifying disease penetrance in the context of frontotemporal dementia.
title: Divergent and Convergent TMEM106B Pathology in Murine Models of Neurodegeneration and Human Disease

finding: The SNP rs1990622 was identified as a risk variant implicated in the pathologic presentation of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Studies showed that editing the risk allele to a protective one rescued cognitive decline and neurodegeneration in an animal model of tauopathy. This indicated that TMEM106B variants can significantly affect the development of neurodegenerative disease pathology, particularly in Alzheimer’s disease.
title: Divergent and Convergent TMEM106B Pathology in Murine Models of Neurodegeneration and Human Disease

finding: The eQTL rs7798226 correlated with reduced expression of MEPCE in Alzheimer’s disease patients. Experimental data indicated that reduction of MEPCE expression led to enhanced tau retinal toxicity in a Drosophila model. These findings suggest that the downregulation of MEPCE linked to rs7798226 may contribute to neurodegeneration in Alzheimer’s disease.
title: A systems-biology approach connects aging mechanisms with Alzheimer’s disease pathogenesis

finding: The study indicated that an allele of IL6 rs2961298 SNP was associated with higher methylation of cg01770232 and increased levels of IL-6. However, it was noted that higher circulating omega-3 HUFA concentrations, which interact with rs2961298, subsequently reduced cg01770232 methylation and IL-6 levels. This finding underlined the potential of omega-3 fatty acids in modulating inflammation associated with lung disorders like COPD and asthma, where IL-6 is a critical inflammatory marker.
title: Evaluation of the Efficacy of Omega-3 Fatty Acids Formulations in the Lipopolysaccharide-Induced Acute Lung Inflammation Rat Model

finding: The SNP rs13246215 was associated with increased replication stress, which was identified as a determinant of ATR inhibitor sensitivity in neuroblastoma cells. This suggests that the presence of this SNP may influence the effectiveness of ATR inhibitors like elimusertib in treating pediatric solid tumors.
title: Elimusertib outperforms standard of care chemotherapy in preclinical patient-derived pediatric solid tumor models

finding: The SNP rs117132860 was identified as the lead candidate causal variant within the melanoma susceptibility locus at 7p21.1. It showed a significant association with melanoma risk (P_meta = 3.83 x 10^-21, OR_G-allele = 0.71), tanning ability (P = 7.63 x 10^-23, OR_G-allele = 1.30), and cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) (P = 3.6 x 10^-8, OR_G-allele = 0.68). Functional studies indicated that rs117132860-G allele favored binding to the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) over the A allele, which weakened binding. Evidence for allele-specific AHR expression following UVB exposure highlighted its functional role in melanoma predisposition.
title: A UVB-responsive common variant at chr7p21.1 confers tanning response and melanoma risk via regulation of the aryl hydrocarbon receptor gene (AHR)

finding: The study identified rs776746 (CYP3A5*3) as a variant that carried an A to G mutation at position 6986 within intron 3, which resulted in aberrant splicing leading to a truncated non-functional CYP3A5 protein. This SNP was significant in the context of prostate cancer, where 90% of Caucasians carried the CYP3A5*3 allele, resulting in reduced enzyme activity, while African Americans predominantly carried wild type variants CYP3A5*1/1 or *1/3, which are associated with high levels of active CYP3A5 protein. The findings indicated that variations in CYP3A5 affected the efficacy of androgen receptor signaling and prostate cancer cell growth.
title: Role of CYP3A5 in modulating androgen receptor signaling and its relevance to African American men with prostate cancer

finding: The SNP rs117026326 at the GTF2I locus was identified as a susceptibility locus for primary Sjögren syndrome based on a comprehensive analysis involving 556,134 autosomal SNPs in 542 cases and 1,050 controls, and later validated in a larger sample of 1,303 cases and 2,727 controls. This SNP was also strongly associated with additional autoimmune diseases including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder.
title: Dermatan Sulfate Is a Potential Master Regulator of IgH via Interactions with Pre-BCR, GTF2I, and BiP ER Complex in Pre-B Lymphoblasts

finding: The SERPINE1 polymorphism rs6092 was related to metabolic traits in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease patients, highlighting its potential relevance in COPD related metabolic dysregulation.
title: Identification of key genes and biological pathways in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: For the trait of mood instability, rs763646 predicted expression of a specific junction in the gene EXOC4, showing strong statistical significance within both LIBD and CMC datasets, suggesting its relevance in mood regulation mechanisms.
title: The genomic basis of mood instability: identification of 46 loci in 363,705 UK Biobank participants, genetic correlation with psychiatric disorders, and association with gene expression and function

finding: The SNP rs6957904 located in the TPK1 gene exhibited a higher distribution of the ancestral allele in populations from North West India and the South West coast, compared to the Gangetic plain populations and notably more than African populations. This finding suggests a distinct genetic signature for the South West coastal group, pointing towards their unique lineage.
title: Genetic affinities and adaptation of the South West coast populations of India

finding: The study revealed that the presence of the PAI-1 single nucleotide polymorphism rs6092 was associated with increased disease severity in COVID-19. Specifically, higher levels of extracellular PAI-1 were linked to enhanced control of SARS-CoV-2 spread. This finding suggested a functional relationship between the rs6092 variant and the regulation of proteases critical for viral life cycles, offering insights into the molecular mechanisms influencing disease outcomes.
title: In-silico docking platform with serine protease inhibitor (SERPIN) structures identifies host cysteine protease targets with significance for SARS-CoV-2

finding: The SNP rs798528 on 7p22.3 had a significant negative association (z=-6.74) with the left putamen, indicating a strong contribution to its connectivity.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: The SNP rs2405442 in the PILRA gene was associated with LOAD, yielding a significant p-value of 1.7 × 10^-7.
title: Weighted burden analysis of exome-sequenced late onset Alzheimer’s cases and controls provides further evidence for a role for PSEN1 and suggests involvement of the PI3K/Akt/GSK-3β and WNT signalling pathways

finding: This SNP was identified as a putative core instrument for serum IGF1 levels, which correlated with the outcome of increased height according to MR Corge estimates, aligning with established biomedical knowledge.
title: MR Corge: Sensitivity analysis of Mendelian randomization based on the core gene hypothesis for polygenic exposures

finding: SNP rs10954213 was strongly associated with alternative 3'UTR usage of the IRF5 gene in whole blood, indicating its role in RNA stability related to susceptibility to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This finding was further supported by detection in 22 other human tissues.
title: Genetic Basis of Alternative Polyadenylation is an Emerging Molecular Phenotype for Human Traits and Diseases

finding: Having a substantial effect on ELMO1 expression, located within an intron, this variant is involved in lymphocyte motility, thus relating to T cell movement and functionality.
title: Linking candidate causal autoimmune variants to T cell networks using genetic and epigenetic screens in primary human T cells

finding: The SNP rs13246288 was identified in a study involving patient-derived xenografts of high-grade serous ovarian cancer, highlighting its potential role in pre-clinical research and therapeutic targeting for this subtype of ovarian cancer.
title: A Scalable 3D High-Content Imaging Protocol for Measuring a Drug Induced DNA Damage Response Using Immunofluorescent Sub-nuclear γH2AX Spots in Patient Derived Ovarian Cancer Organoids

finding: The rs12539172 SNP, located in the 3' region of NYAP1, had the strongest associations with the proteins PILRB and PILRA, showcasing a dose-dependent reduction in protein expression with the minor allele in all age groups, which implicates this SNP in AD-related immune modulation.
title: Manifestations of genetic risk for Alzheimer’s Disease in the blood: a cross-sectional multi-omic analysis in healthy adults aged 18-90+

finding: The variant rs1859788, which codes for a missense mutation in PILRA, was linked to reduced protein levels and may influence the protective effects associated with the R78 substitution, relating back to potential increases in microglial activity and implications in Alzheimer’s disease risk.
title: Manifestations of genetic risk for Alzheimer’s Disease in the blood: a cross-sectional multi-omic analysis in healthy adults aged 18-90+

finding: The SNP rs11761270, which overlaps with the CpG site cg12169700 in <MAD1L1>, was found to be located in the same linkage disequilibrium (LD) block as a recently identified PTSD-associated SNP. Carriers of the minor allele of rs11761270 showed decreased levels of methylation and were at increased risk of developing PTSD. This finding corresponded with the overall result where PTSD cases demonstrated a reduction in methylation from pre-to post-deployment, linking <MAD1L1> methylation profiles to PTSD risk.
title: Meta-analysis of longitudinal epigenome-wide association studies of military cohorts reveals multiple CpG sites associated with post-traumatic stress disorder

finding: The finding highlighted a significant association between rs77155650 and neutrophil content in lung tissue, with a p-value of 9.7 × 10−11. This SNP, located near the CUX1 transcription factor gene, was linked to neutrophil infiltration and the regulation of various immune response genes.
title: Age, Sex, and Genetics Influence the Abundance of Infiltrating Immune Cells in Human Tissues

finding: This RNA editing QTL was identified in both the peripheral blood and brain regions of Alzheimer's patients, reinforcing its role in neurodegenerative pathogenesis through associations with differential editing sites.
title: Genetic control of RNA editing in Neurodegenerative disease

finding: The SNP rs587776523 was associated with the dominant delayed-onset hearing loss phenotype DFNA50, demonstrated in the mouse model carrying the <Mir96<sup>14C>A</sup>> mutation. This mutation caused complete hearing loss across all frequencies and age groups, assessed through auditory brainstem response (ABR) and distortion product otoacoustic emission (DPOAE) tests, with significant auditory loss observed as early as 4 weeks of age.
title: Targeted genome editing restores auditory function in adult mice with progressive hearing loss caused by a human microRNA mutation

finding: The SNP rs587776522, alongside rs587776523, was identified as responsible for autosomal dominant non-syndromic progressive hearing loss DFNA50. This finding was validated through the characterization of the <Mir96<sup>14C>A</sup>> mutation in mouse models, where hearing loss became progressively more severe with age, confirming the mutational impact on auditory capabilities.
title: Targeted genome editing restores auditory function in adult mice with progressive hearing loss caused by a human microRNA mutation

finding: The lead SNP rs3211938 at the novel locus CD36 was found to be common in African Americans (MAF=10%) but near-monomorphic in European Americans (MAF<0.01%). It showed large effect sizes for QT interval, increasing it by 3.70 ms (p=6x10^-10) and was associated with the TP segment (p=1x10^-13).
title: Multi-ethnic genome-wide association study of decomposed cardioelectric phenotypes illustrates strategies to identify and characterize evidence of shared genetic effects for complex traits

finding: The SNP rs3211938 was identified as a Tier 1 AFR_high ancestry-specific eQTL for the gene CD36. It had a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.077 in the AFR_high population and 0.0020 in the AFR_low population. This variant was linked to higher levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol in several multi-ancestry genome-wide association studies (GWAS) that included African Americans.
title: Gene expression in African Americans and Latinos reveals ancestry-specific patterns of genetic architecture

finding: The rs61735090 variant was connected to Alzheimer's disease (AD), as it was identified based on joint under-expression in RNA and protein signals, indicating its involvement in AD pathophysiology.
title: The functional impact of rare variation across the regulatory cascade

finding: The SNP rs10954213 was found to be in tight linkage disequilibrium with other SNPs associated with alternative polyadenylation (APA) for the IRF5 3'UTR. The study detailed the association of this SNP with glucocorticoid-mediated APA, indicating its role in immune regulation, particularly linked to identified immune disorders.
title: Glucocorticoids Mediate Transcriptome-wide Alternative Polyadenylation: Mechanisms and Functional Implications

finding: The mutation V17M (rs11557408) was predicted to be disease causing and localized in a highly conservative region of the SBDS protein. It was not reported in any previous studies.
title: Prediction of Four Novel SNPs V17M, R11H, A66T, and F57S in the SBDS Gene Possibly Associated with Formation of Shwachman-Diamond Syndrome, using an Insilico Approach

finding: The mutation R11H (rs11557409) was predicted to be disease causing and was located in a highly conservative region of the SBDS protein. This finding had not been previously reported.
title: Prediction of Four Novel SNPs V17M, R11H, A66T, and F57S in the SBDS Gene Possibly Associated with Formation of Shwachman-Diamond Syndrome, using an Insilico Approach

finding: The mutation A66T (rs367842164) was predicted to be disease causing and found in a highly conserved region of the SBDS protein, which had not been reported in earlier studies.
title: Prediction of Four Novel SNPs V17M, R11H, A66T, and F57S in the SBDS Gene Possibly Associated with Formation of Shwachman-Diamond Syndrome, using an Insilico Approach

finding: The mutation F57S (rs376960114) was predicted to be disease causing and was located in a highly conservative region of the SBDS protein. This finding was novel according to previous literature.
title: Prediction of Four Novel SNPs V17M, R11H, A66T, and F57S in the SBDS Gene Possibly Associated with Formation of Shwachman-Diamond Syndrome, using an Insilico Approach

finding: This SNP was part of four SNVs that showed significant frequency differences between Tibetans and Hans, with a linkage disequilibrium (LD) greater than 0.8, thus indicating its potential role in HAA.
title: Characterization of Structural Variation in Tibetans Reveals New Evidence of High-altitude Adaptation and Introgression
