finding: The SNP rs17544225 was associated with a negative relationship to autoimmune disease risk (R = -0.84) in a region overlapping the gene GRB10, which is involved in immune response. Besides, 17 of the 20 introgressed variants in this window were splicing quantitative trait loci (sQTL), enhancing intron excision, thereby suggesting that Neanderthal introgressed alleles influence splicing or regulation of GRB10, contributing to immune response modulation.
title: Quantifying the contribution of Neanderthal introgression to the heritability of complex traits

finding: The rs7794745 SNP was identified as an autism spectrum disorder (ASD)-associated SNP located within the CNTNAP2 locus. Analysis revealed that this SNP is situated approximately 280 bp from a differentially methylated region that overlaps with a human-specific enhancer identified in the study. The major allele of rs7794745 represents a human-specific substitution (A>T) when compared to chimpanzees and rhesus macaques, indicating an evolutionary change linked to a neuropsychiatric disorder.
title: Evolution of regulatory signatures in primate cortical neurons at cell type resolution

finding: The SNP rs12113434 was linked to the interplay between Wnt signaling and vitamin D in solid cancers, providing evidence that modulations in this pathway are critical for CRC pathogenesis, particularly concerning the over-activation of β-catenin.
title: SIRT1 mediates the antagonism of Wnt/β-catenin pathway by vitamin D in colon carcinoma cells

finding: The SNP rs12113385 was positively associated with metastatic colonization as detailed in the study by Schaller and Agudo. This research highlighted the mechanisms through which cancer cells evade immune surveillance during metastasis, indicating a potential link between this SNP and the biological processes involved in cancer metastasis. The study underscored the relevance of immune checkpoints and cancer hallmarks, providing a comprehensive view of how this genetic variant may play a role in the metastatic process.
title: Metastases arise as new cancers from cells of target organs transformed by cell-free chromatin particles released from dying cancer cells

finding: The SNP rs17148944 was considered a very high risk variant based on analysis with HaploReg v4 and RegulomeDB, contributing to the estimation of warfarin maintenance dose in polypharmacy scenarios.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: The non-coding variant rs12537277 was classified as very high risk according to the analysis findings, highlighting its potential influence on gene regulation and expression in cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase activity.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This SNP was noted as a very high risk variant, associated with adverse effects from the anti-hepatitis B drug, Pradefovir, in the Chinese population, indicating its clinical relevance.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Identified as a very high risk SNP through RegulomeDB analysis, suggesting potential effects on transcription factor binding and gene expression.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This SNP was classified as very high risk due to its role in possibly affecting phenotype expression, indicating its influence on POR activity.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: The variant rs10954732 was deemed very high risk based on the computational analysis indicating its likely impact on transcriptional regulation.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Found to be a very high risk SNP, its contribution to gene regulation suggests a significant effect on POR enzyme activity.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This SNP was considered very high risk, likely influencing miRNA interactions and consequently, gene expression.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Identified as a very high risk variant in miRNA target sites, this SNP was shown to disrupt miRNA regulation, altering gene expression.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This SNP was classified as very high risk due to its impact in the miRNA target site, affecting regulatory mechanisms of gene expression.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Found to be a high risk SNP based on two out of three tools analyzing its impact on miRNA target interactions.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This variant, Q90P, was part of a subset of very high risk missense mutations predicted to disrupt catalytic sites within the enzyme's mechanism.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: The G535S variant was implicated as a very high risk mutation affecting enzyme function by altering catalytic mechanisms.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Associated with significant phenotypic effects, this G535D mutation was classified as very high risk for its role at the enzyme catalytic site.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: The G537S/R mutation was identified as very high risk, influencing the enzyme’s active sites relevant for NADP binding.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This G537V variant was recognized as a very high risk mutation impactful on enzyme activity.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: The variant in the FAD binding region was associated with complete loss of POR enzymatic activity, categorizing it as very high risk.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Classified as very high risk for leading to total loss of POR activity, arising from its location in FAD binding sites.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This SNP also posed a very high risk due to its association with functional loss in POR activity.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Identified as very high risk, this variant's effects on miRNA targets highlight its potential regulatory importance in gene expression.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: The rs5011436 variant within the TMEM106B locus was both a fQTL and a cis-eQTL influencing TMEM106B expression in excitatory neurons. This SNP was implicated as a risk allele for Alzheimer’s disease and linked with frontotemporal dementia, demonstrating its role in influencing neuronal subtype proportions.
title: Cell-subtype specific effects of genetic variation in the aging and Alzheimer cortex

finding: In the study, SNP rs55752599 was located about 280kb away from the left anchor of a candidate chromatin loop. This loop was formed by a CTCF binding site derived from an L1MC1 transposable element, which anchored a regulatory interaction between distant cis-regulatory elements and the NCAPG2 promoter. The presence of enhancer marks in the syntenic region in mouse indicated that these elements bore enhancer potential, but they did not regulate the same target genes as in humans due to the absence of the L1MC1 TE and the resulting chromatin looping.
title: Widespread contribution of transposable elements to the rewiring of mammalian 3D genomes and gene regulation

finding: The genetic variant rs3757536, located in the CADPS2 gene, was identified as a modifier of the age of onset in PSEN1 p.E280A Alzheimer's disease patients. This finding related to the involvement of CADPS2 in neurodegenerative disorders, emphasizing its potential role in conditions associated with neuronal development and signaling, particularly in the context of familial Alzheimer's disease.
title: Homozygous CADPS2 mutations cause neurodegenerative disease with Lewy bodies in parrots

finding: The IBD-associated variant rs1456896 was found to increase in frequency and associated with the expression of IRF1, which is known to provide protection against infections.
title: Genetic adaptation to pathogens and increased risk of inflammatory disorders in post-Neolithic Europe

finding: The SNP rs199473435 was associated with the variant <italic>KCNH2</italic>:c.2717C>T:p.(Ser906Leu). This variant was deemed likely pathogenic and resulted in reduced current density in KCNH2-p.S906L-Hz by 35.6%, indicating a moderate loss of function leading to incomplete penetrance of Long QT Syndrome type 2 (LQTS2).
title: Reclassification of a likely pathogenic Dutch founder variant in KCNH2; implications of reduced penetrance

finding: The SNP rs11771241 in the PILRA/B locus showed colocalization with retinal edQTLs and was associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD). The edSite was intronic, while another site was predicted to introduce a missense variant causing a K106E protein substitution.
title: The retinal RNA editome is concentrated in photoreceptor-specific genes and genetically linked to vision loss

finding: The variant rs17853284, also known as P228L in POR, was confirmed to be linked to lower testosterone levels. This was established through various enzyme kinetic studies, where the P228L variant exhibited significantly reduced activities in key steroid metabolizing cytochromes, including a 25% reduction in CYP3A4 activity, over 40% reduction in CYP3A5 and CYP2C9 activities, and only 27% of wild type activity in CYP17A1's 17,20 lyase activity responsible for producing the androgen precursor DHEA. This overall impairment in steroidogenesis was critical in explaining the lower testosterone levels associated with individuals carrying this variant.
title: Loss of protein stability and function caused by POR-variation P228L

finding: The SNP rs79520962 emerged as a genome-wide significant SNP for pure meaning in life, also identified through GWAS-by-subtraction of depressive symptoms. It demonstrated a larger effect size of 0.304 and a p-value of 1.86×10^-8. This SNP was previously recognized in the Baselmans and Bartels (2018) study, showing similar effects, although this later look-up did not reveal other associations for this SNP.
title: Distinguishing Happiness and Meaning in Life from Depressive Symptoms: a GWAS-by-subtraction study in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs74338692 was associated with increased GSAP transcript levels in the brain and demonstrated a significant effect size (p < 0.001) after conducting meta-analysis across 13 brain regions. This SNP showed particular relevance to Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk, where it was found to be a major genetic factor modulating GSAP expression, potentially influencing AD pathogenesis. Furthermore, this finding was supported by linkage disequilibrium analysis indicating that rs74338692 harbored regulatory properties that might explain its connection to elevated GSAP levels in the brain.
title: GSAP regulates mitochondrial function through the Mitochondria-associated ER membrane in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs3779031 was associated with an increased risk of developmental dyslexia specifically in females, as reported by Gu et al. (2018). This finding highlighted the sex-specific effects of variants in the CNTNAP2 gene on developmental disorders.
title: Sexual dimorphism in the social behaviour of Cntnap2 KO mice correlates with disrupted synaptic connectivity and increased microglial activity in the anterior cingulate cortex of males

finding: The SNP rs987456 was similarly associated with an increased risk of developmental dyslexia in females, but not in males, according to Gu et al. (2018). This finding further underscored the notion that mutations in the CNTNAP2 gene present sex-specific implications in neurodevelopmental conditions.
title: Sexual dimorphism in the social behaviour of Cntnap2 KO mice correlates with disrupted synaptic connectivity and increased microglial activity in the anterior cingulate cortex of males

finding: The SNP rs10276677 was described with T2D GWAS signals and evaluated for causal relationships in gene expression and chromatin accessibility. This SNP was noted to lie in a causal region for the GDSME gene.
title: Population-scale skeletal muscle single-nucleus multi-omic profiling reveals extensive context specific genetic regulation

finding: The SNP rs700037 colocalized with a caQTL specific to the type 1 muscle fiber cell-type cluster, associated with independent eQTL signals for the lincRNA gene AC023095.1, demonstrating causality in gene expression.
title: Population-scale skeletal muscle single-nucleus multi-omic profiling reveals extensive context specific genetic regulation

finding: The study provided evidence suggesting that the SNP rs13225673, which was located in a region associated with KIF2C, correlated with the regulation of cell migration and invasion via modulation of microtubule dynamics and focal adhesion turnover. This was especially relevant to context of cancer biology, as KIF2C emerged as a critical interactor with Nek2A, highlighting its potential role in improving patient outcomes in cancers characterized by centrosome amplification.
title: Less is More: Nek2A Unclusters Extra Centrosomes and Induces Cell Death in Cancer Cells via KIF2C Interaction

finding: The SNP rs705379 was associated with a strong relationship to the DNA methylation state of multiple CpGs at the PON1 locus. A genotype of A showed a high DNA methylation state of over 50%, while the G genotype corresponded to a decrease in methylation levels below 25% for some CpGs. This effect was consistent across samples within a genotype, demonstrating its influence on the methylation state.
title: Identification of tissue-specific and common methylation quantitative trait loci in healthy individuals using MAGAR

finding: Lead SNP rs62443772, associated with GLI3, was found to interact significantly with rs76244841 in segment 9, showing potential implications for facial morphology.
title: Insights into the genetic architecture of the human face

finding: The rs1990621 variant was identified as a FTLD-protective variant that was also associated with an increased neuronal proportion. This finding indicated a potential role of TMEM106B in modulating neuronal resilience in neurodegenerative contexts.
title: TMEM106B C-terminal fragments aggregate and drive neurodegenerative proteinopathy

finding: The rs1990622 variant was found to associate with Alzheimer's disease and was implicated in the regulation of TMEM106B expression within human brain tissues. This suggested a possible pathway through which genetic variation influenced Alzheimer's pathology.
title: TMEM106B C-terminal fragments aggregate and drive neurodegenerative proteinopathy

finding: The SNP rs13246274 was associated with arginine depletion in human cancers, as detailed in the study by Nelakurti et al. (2021). This depletion was linked to somatic missense mutations that could indicate adaptation to altered pH in tumors, notably resulting in a balance shift from arginine to lysine which is known to affect protein solubility.
title: Computational investigation of missense somatic mutations in cancer and potential links to pH-dependence and proteostasis

finding: The SNP rs3807866 was identified within the gene Transmembrane Protein 106B (TMEM106B) and was associated with Lifetime Anxiety Disorder with a p-value of 4.8×10−8. It formally replicated in studies related to Neuroticism and had consistent effects across Anxiety Disorder studies.
title: A Major Role for Common Genetic Variation in Anxiety Disorders

finding: SNP rs1990620 was in high linkage disequilibrium with rs3807866 and was previously implicated in expression levels of TMEM106B, suggesting a causal role in anxiety disorders through its impact on cellular processes linked to the TMEM106B locus.
title: A Major Role for Common Genetic Variation in Anxiety Disorders

finding: The SNP rs56226325 was associated with the MADIL1 locus with a p-value of 4.68×10−10 in the GAD-2 anxiety study and supported by its presence in the case-control analysis for anxiety disorders, underscoring its relevance across psychiatric traits.
title: Reproducible Risk Loci and Psychiatric Comorbidities in Anxiety: Results from ~200,000 Million Veteran Program Participants

finding: The rs13235874 SNP was associated with the regulation of microRNAs, specifically within the context of the miR-200 family. This family of microRNAs was known to be involved in processes like epithelial-mesenchymal transition and had implications as circulating cancer biomarkers. The findings highlighted the critical role of microRNAs in cellular processes, linking genetic variations such as rs13235874 to significant regulatory functions.
title: Combinatorial microRNA activity is essential for the transition of pluripotent cells from proliferation into dormancy

finding: The SNP rs11982272, located on chromosome 7, showed a significant association with ADHD+DBDs with a P-value of 4.38×10^-8 and an odds ratio of 0.83 in the GWAS meta-analysis. Like the other loci, it contributed to the understanding of the genetics behind the comorbid condition.
title: Identification of risk variants and characterization of the polygenic architecture of disruptive behavior disorders in the context of ADHD

finding: The SNP rs12113219 was associated with ADAR-mediated editing patterns in the context of reovirus infection. The editing changes introduced by reovirus infection were nuanced, indicating that rs12113219 may play a role in influencing immune regulation and cellular signaling pathways. Furthermore, the SNP's impact was noted in the overrepresentation of genes related to immune response and metabolism, supporting the hypothesis that rs12113219 could be a critical locus for understanding dynamic editing in response to viral challenges.
title: Reovirus infection induces transcriptome-wide unique A-to-I editing changes in the murine fibroblasts

finding: The A insertion at rs71561908 led to stronger transcriptional repression of the SEC61G gene after dexamethasone treatment in NK cells. SEC61G is crucial for the translocation of proteins into the endoplasmic reticulum and has roles in viral replication.
title: Genetic control of the dynamic transcriptional response to immune stimuli and glucocorticoids at single cell resolution

finding: The SNP rs606231147 was identified in relation to higher PADIT-seq activity for the risk allele, contributing to preaxial polydactyly by creating multiple overlapping HOXD13 active 8-mers, indicating a significant role in limb malformation.
title: Overlapping binding sites underlie TF genomic occupancy

finding: Similar to rs606231147, rs606231230 was highlighted for its higher PADIT-seq activity affecting the risk allele for preaxial polydactyly by producing multiple overlapping HOXD13 active 8-mers, providing evidence for its role in gene regulation pertaining to limb malformations.
title: Overlapping binding sites underlie TF genomic occupancy

finding: The SNP rs60600003 was found to reside within a mammal level 2 cis-regulatory element (cCRE) located in the intron of the gene ELMO1, which is involved in phagocytosis. This cCRE was determined to be accessible exclusively in microglia, indicating that the presence of this MS risk variant could selectively affect the expression of ELMO1 in microglial cells. The findings highlighted the role of this variant in linking microglia regulatory elements to multiple sclerosis (MS), suggesting that gene regulatory effects of MS risk variants could be interpreted through the lens of enhancer-gene predictions.
title: Comparative single cell epigenomic analysis of gene regulatory programs in the rodent and primate neocortex

finding: The SNP rs13225744 was linked to the expression of Fibroblast Activation Protein (FAP), a critical marker in CAF biology. As suggested by Lindner et al. (2021), variations at this locus were implicated in the response of tumors to targeted therapies, emphasizing FAP's role in mediating immune suppression in cancer therapy.
title: Stromal depletion by TALEN-edited universal hypoimmunogenic FAP-CAR T cells enables infiltration and anti-tumor cytotoxicity of tumor antigen-targeted CAR-T immunotherapy

finding: The missense variant p.Thr8Ile (rs62473563) in <italic>PRSS2</italic> was found to contribute independently to the risk of CF meconium ileus, with a statistical significance of p=0.011. This SNP also functioned as a pancreas eQTL with a p-value of 1.4e-4, indicating a reduction in <italic>PRSS2</italic> expression.
title: High Quality Phasing Using Linked-Read Whole Genome Sequencing of Patient Cohorts Informs Genetic Understanding of Complex Traits

finding: The SNP rs3757377 was associated with an increased risk of disease (beta=0.29, p=5.2e-4) and identified separately as a significant marker in the context of meconium ileus risk. Its allele 'T' had a frequency of 41% among the 10XG samples.
title: High Quality Phasing Using Linked-Read Whole Genome Sequencing of Patient Cohorts Informs Genetic Understanding of Complex Traits

finding: This SNP was linked to non-CF pancreatitis risk and demonstrated allelic heterogeneity in a previous GWAS. Its significance as a common pancreatitis risk allele reinforces the relationship between it and alterations in <italic>PRSS1</italic> expression.
title: High Quality Phasing Using Linked-Read Whole Genome Sequencing of Patient Cohorts Informs Genetic Understanding of Complex Traits

finding: The variant rs1799886 was noted to have a minor allele frequency of 43.5% and was associated with meconium ileus, showcasing an association signal distinct from the deletion polymorphism. It was shown to act in 'cis' with p.Thr8Ile in a significant proportion of haplotypes.
title: High Quality Phasing Using Linked-Read Whole Genome Sequencing of Patient Cohorts Informs Genetic Understanding of Complex Traits

finding: In a study investigating the relationship between genetic variants and obesity, the SNP rs10487505 was found to be associated with circulating leptin levels and obesity in a sex-specific manner. The analysis indicated that while rs10487505 did not correlate with LEP gene expression, it influenced post-transcriptional mechanisms, possibly through the regulation of long non-coding RNAs. It was observed that the lncOb, which is linked to fat mass, had a leptin-lowering effect related to this SNP, further supporting the notion of post-transcriptional regulation impacting body fat percentage and leptin serum levels.
title: Sex-specific role of epigenetic modification of a leptin upstream enhancer in the adipose tissue

finding: The variant c.1521_1523delCTT (rs1801178) in the CFTR gene was known to cause recessive cystic fibrosis (MIM:219700) and was hypothesized to provide protection against cholera and tuberculosis. It was identified within the context of a study examining HetExc variants and was one of the two variants with 'Pathogenic' status in the ClinVar database.
title: Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium in the Large Scale Genomic Sequencing Era

finding: The lead SNP rs17168486 was identified as a key eQTL influencing islet expression of the DGKB gene and co-localized with T2D GWAS signals. However, luciferase assays did not reveal significant allelic effects on transcriptional activity of constructs containing this SNP.
title: Influence of genetic variants on gene expression in human pancreatic islets – implications for type 2 diabetes

finding: The lead eSNP rs10231021 was also found to be a significant islet-specific eQTL associated with DGKB gene expression, demonstrating its role in modulating transcription relevant to T2D.
title: Influence of genetic variants on gene expression in human pancreatic islets – implications for type 2 diabetes

finding: This SNP was shown to be in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs10231021 and was identified as a significant variant influencing both DGKB expression and associated with T2D risk.
title: Influence of genetic variants on gene expression in human pancreatic islets – implications for type 2 diabetes

finding: rs10953142 directly linked to PON3 protein levels through common variant analysis, alongside associations in the rare variant analysis.
title: Genetic determinants of plasma protein levels in the Estonian population

finding: The rs63750451 variant was found to be a germline nonsense mutation in the PMS2 gene present in two patients. Although this variant was documented as pathogenic, there was no indication of mismatch repair deficiency (dMMR) in the patients’ tumours, as their tumour mutation burden was measured at less than 1 mutation/Mb. This suggests a complex role of this mutation in cancer development.
title: Activation of Wnt/β-catenin signalling by mutually exclusive FBXW11 and CTNNB1 hotspot mutations drives salivary gland basal cell adenoma

finding: The study established that the rs756747-T variant of the Reelin gene was significantly associated with a higher likelihood of alcohol consumption, with a p-value of 4 × 10^-9. This genetic variant was linked to addiction traits, implying that impairment in Reelin signaling could disrupt inhibitory control, particularly in the context of substance use behaviors.
title: Reelin deficiency contributes to long-term behavioral abnormalities induced by chronic adolescent exposure to Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol in mice

finding: The SNP rs12699415, located in an intron of the MAD1L1 gene, was characterized as having a 36% posterior probability of causality for IPF, which was significantly higher than that of other variants in its credible set. This finding indicated a connection to decreased MAD1L1 expression in heart tissue, pointing to its relevance in IPF susceptibility.
title: Genome-wide association study of susceptibility to idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

finding: The SNP rs12113228 was associated with the use of beta-adrenergic blocking agents, which demonstrated an effect on cutaneous melanoma survival based on a nation-wide Swedish population-based retrospective register study. The context of this finding related to improved patient outcomes in melanoma cases treated with beta-blockers, highlighting their potential role in enhancing therapeutic responses.
title: Intracranial tumors elicit systemic sympathetic hyperactivity that limits immunotherapeutic responses

finding: The rs62621812 SNP was identified as the lead variant for both the bone mineral density (BMD) locus and the associated sQTL. This rare missense variant was shown to impact the expression of novel ZNF800 isoforms, with findings indicating that the long isoform associated with bone mineral density had an increase in BMD. The specific isoforms expressed from the haplotype harboring the alternative allele were observed to decrease during osteoblast differentiation.
title: Long-read proteogenomics to connect disease-associated sQTLs to the protein isoform effectors of disease

finding: The rs17451754 SNP was located in an open chromatin peak associated with Barrett's oesophagus. It was predicted to disrupt the binding of a transcriptional activator, highlighting its potential contribution to the etiology of the disease.
title: The metaplastic precursor state to oesophageal adenocarcinoma represents reversion to a transient epithelial cell state in the developing oesophagus

finding: The SNP rs13227429, associated with the BRAF gene, demonstrated a significant association with FVC (p=5.6×10^-9). This represented a novel connection between mutations in lung cancer and lung function.
title: Immune-mediated genetic pathways resulting in pulmonary function impairment increase lung cancer susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs4731702 was associated with type II diabetes and cholesterol levels. It exhibited maternally-restricted cis-regulatory associations with the expression of the maternally expressed transcription factor KLF14 in adipose tissue, suggesting its role in regulating adiposity. Additionally, eQTL analysis indicated that rs4731702 was enriched for trans-associations with KLF family transcription factor binding sites in subcutaneous white adipose tissue, indicating KLF14's potential as a master transcriptional regulator in adipose tissue.
title: Parent-of-origin effects propagate through networks to shape metabolic traits

finding: The SNP rs972283 was also linked to type II diabetes and cholesterol levels, similar to rs4731702. Like rs4731702, it showed maternally-restricted cis-regulatory associations with KLF14 expression in adipose tissue, underscoring its possible involvement in metabolic phenotypes related to adiposity. This indicates that both SNPs interact through their regulatory roles affecting KLF14, contributing to phenotypic variations.
title: Parent-of-origin effects propagate through networks to shape metabolic traits

finding: The SNP rs7789146 was identified as a risk variant associated with atrial fibrillation (AF), residing within a cardiomyocyte-specific cis-regulatory element (cCRE) at the KCNH2 locus. It displayed decreased enhancer activity when compared to the non-risk allele in human pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes, indicating its functional importance. Following CRISPR/Cas9 deletion of this cCRE, there was a correlating decrease in KCNH2 expression and an observable prolongation of action potential repolarization, linking the variant directly to cardiac electrophysiological dysfunction.
title: Cardiac Cell Type-Specific Gene Regulatory Programs and Disease Risk Association

finding: The SNP rs7789585 was also categorized as a risk variant for atrial fibrillation and was found in association with the same cardiomyocyte-specific cCRE at the KCNH2 locus as rs7789146. It demonstrated reduced enhancer activity compared to the non-risk allele in differentiated cardiomyocytes. Similar to rs7789146, deletion of this cCRE led to lower expression of KCNH2 and prolonged action potential duration, underscoring its role in cardiac function and AF pathophysiology.
title: Cardiac Cell Type-Specific Gene Regulatory Programs and Disease Risk Association

finding: The rs3800631 SNP was identified as a schizophrenia risk variant specifically located within the DGKI gene. The study's analysis revealed that this SNP was significantly enriched in neuronal A compartment chromatin during the differentiation of human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) into neurons, indicating its role in the regulatory framework associated with neurodevelopment and schizophrenia.
title: Schizophrenia Risk Mapping and Functional Engineering of the 3D Genome in Three Neuronal Subtypes

finding: The study identified that SNP rs782881 was the most frequent mutant allele across Europe, Asia, and the Americas, with frequencies of 48%, 54%, and 42% respectively. This SNP was linked to higher expression levels of the AKR1B10 gene, which was associated with increased lung cancer incidence and higher daily cigarette consumption. This correlation suggested a potential connection between the presence of this SNP and the risk of lung cancer.
title: Systems biology analysis of publicly available transcriptomic data reveals a critical link between AKR1B10 gene expression, smoking and occurrence of lung cancer

finding: SNP rs782510 was noted as the most common mutant allele in Africa with a frequency of 78%. Analysis indicated that this SNP might affect gene expression due to its role as an e-QTL. The lower frequency of rs782510 and its association with lower AKR1B10 expression in Africa correlated with lower lung cancer incidence and cigarette consumption, proposing that this SNP may be protective against lung cancer.
title: Systems biology analysis of publicly available transcriptomic data reveals a critical link between AKR1B10 gene expression, smoking and occurrence of lung cancer

finding: The missense variant rs713598 of the TAS2R38 gene showed the most significant association with PROP bitterness ratings. It was reported that variants in this gene influenced participants' perception of bitterness, specifically leading to significant differences in PROP ratings between its genotypes (C:C, C:G, and G:G).
title: Worldwide study of the taste of bitter medicines and their modifiers

finding: The SNP rs13236005 was associated with the mek/erk/mir-21 signaling pathway, which was found to be critical in osimertinib resistance among EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cells. This finding indicated a possible genetic underpinning of resistance mechanisms affecting treatment efficacy.
title: Mechanisms analysis for Formononetin counteracted-Osimertinib resistance in Non-small-cell lung cancer cells: from the insight into the gene transcriptional level

finding: A ~13kbp deletion on chromosome 7, which included the EPO promoter, was associated with hemoglobin (HGB) and hematocrit (HCT) traits, and was in strong LD with rs4729607. This deletion was previously implicated in affecting the expression of iron metabolism and erythropoiesis-related genes such as TFR2 and EPHB4.
title: Structural variation across 138,134 samples in the TOPMed consortium

finding: The SNP rs7789146 was identified in the context of a study examining the KCNH2 promoter and its associated enhancer linked to atrial fibrillation. This variant was validated for its role in enhancer function via CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing in a human pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocyte line. The study demonstrated significant enhancer-promoter co-accessibility, as assessed through snATAC-seq data, with statistically significant improvements in f1-score and recall, indicating that the enhancer linked to this SNP functionally affects the KCNH2 promoter in cardiomyocytes.
title: Enhlink infers distal and context-specific enhancer-promoter linkages

finding: The SNP rs1800795, located in the IL-6 gene, demonstrated a significant effect on cognitive impairment in Asian breast cancer patients. This research underscored the role of inflammatory cytokine polymorphisms in the cognitive side effects of breast cancer therapy, thereby aiding in the understanding of patient responses to treatment accordingly.
title: An Ensemble Learning Approach for Cancer Drug Prediction

finding: SNP rs4917014, located near the IKZF1 locus, displayed a significantly stronger effect on SLE in East Asians with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.33 (P=5.18E-29), compared to Europeans where the OR was 1.16 (P=1.34E-06). The Cochran's Q-test indicated a significant difference in effect sizes between the two ancestral groups.
title: Identification of 38 novel loci for systemic lupus erythematosus and genetic heterogeneity that may underly population disparities in this disease

finding: The SNP rs13236025 was associated with altered activity in the Kv11.1 channel, which was found to play a role in reprogramming epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in colon cancer. The study indicated that modulation of this channel inhibited TGFbeta signaling via activation of Calcineurin, suggesting a significant link between this SNP and neoplastic processes in epithelial cells.
title: Voltage-dependent volume regulation controls epithelial cell extrusion and morphology

finding: The rs76350051 SNP showed a robust association with bipolar disorder (BIP), demonstrated by a MAF of 0.0004, an Info score of 0.04, and an impressive p-value of 2.47 x 10^-37. This finding pointed to the potential relevance of this rare SNP in BIP.
title: Increasing the resolution and precision of psychiatric GWAS by re-imputing summary statistics using a large, diverse reference panel

finding: The rs12539712 SNP was robustly associated with PILRB and PILRA protein expression levels. The study reported that reduced levels of PILRA protein in carriers of this SNP could contribute to AD risk, given its known involvement in inflammatory processes.
title: Manifestations of genetic risk for Alzheimer’s Disease in the blood: a cross-sectional multiomic analysis in healthy adults aged 18-90+

finding: This variant was identified in the POT1 gene, demonstrating a strong association with telomere length.
title: Novel genetic determinants of telomere length from a trans-ethnic analysis of 109,122 whole genome sequences in TOPMed

finding: The rs17228616 SNP, found in the 3'-untranslated region of the AChE gene, interrupted the recognition of AChE by miR-608. Carriers of the less abundant allele of this SNP exhibited reduced blockade of AChE by miR-608, resulting in lower cholinergic tone. This finding indicated a connection to elevated blood pressure, increased inflammatory biomarkers, and a blockade of amygdala stress reactions in the prefrontal cortex.
title: Ribosomal protein L24 modulates mammalian microRNA processing and transfer RNA fragment production

finding: The study found that rs58407391, which resides in the gene NXPH1, was associated with obesity. This finding was significant as it was uncovered by the HC-GWAS method, demonstrating its effectiveness in identifying new loci related to body mass index (BMI), an important phenotype for understanding body shape and fitness. The traditional GWAS did not identify this SNP, highlighting the advantages of the HC-GWAS approach in detecting relevant genetic factors.
title: Non-parametric GWAS: Another View on Genome-wide Association Study

finding: The EGFR rs2227983 polymorphism was analyzed and associated with breast cancer phenotype, contributing to understanding cancer genetics.
title: The Identification of Key Genes and Biological Pathways in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome and its Complications by Next Generation Squancing (NGS) and Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The CAV2 rs2270188 SNP was part of an interaction study that associated it with fat intake and type 2 diabetes risk.
title: The Identification of Key Genes and Biological Pathways in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome and its Complications by Next Generation Squancing (NGS) and Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The SNP rs11974335 was part of a locus affecting neuronal proportion significantly tied to several brain traits, confirming its relevance in gene regulation linked to neural health.
title: Brain expression quantitative trait locus and network analysis reveals downstream effects and putative drivers for brain-related diseases

finding: As one of the novel SNPs associated with hsCRP identified in the current study, rs78821961 pointed to its potential involvement in chronic inflammation.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: This SNP, marked as novel in the context of hsCRP levels, was recognized for its significance in the genetic susceptibility to chronic inflammation.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: The study identified rs80348264 as a novel SNP associated with hsCRP levels, revealing its possible impact in chronic inflammatory processes.
title: A genome-wide association study of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein in a large Korean population highlights its role in cholesterol metabolism

finding: The SNP rs2188580 located upstream of IL6 was found to be strongly associated with platelet count in East Asians (p_EAS=2.8x10^-9), marking it as a distinct finding linking IL6 to hematological traits.
title: Trans-ethnic and ancestry-specific blood-cell genetics in 746,667 individuals from 5 global populations

finding: This SNP was linked to autism and exhibited significant frequency differences among populations, highlighting potential genetic factors influencing autism susceptibility in Ukrainians relative to other European populations.
title: Genome Diversity in Ukraine

finding: The SNP rs12113269 appeared relevant as it was implicated in chemoresistance in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. This finding contributed to the understanding of the tumor microenvironment's role in cancer progression and treatment response.
title: Spatial analysis of HPV associated cervical intraepithelial neoplastic tissues demonstrate distinct immune signatures associated with cervical cancer progression

finding: The risk allele of SNP rs4487645 was identified as being highly associated with increased expression of CDCA7L, which in turn was linked to increased DNA methylation levels at 47 CpG sites. This suggests that the effects of rs4487645 on CDCA7L expression may play a significant role in the pathogenesis of multiple myeloma.
title: Genome-wide identification of genes regulating DNA methylation using genetic anchors for causal inference

finding: The intronic polymorphism rs12540874 A>G of the GRB10 gene was associated with high birth weight. This finding related to the research concerning the role of GRB10 in fetal growth regulation, demonstrating a genetic influence on the optimal size at birth and implicating it in the mechanisms that determine susceptibility to disorders such as obesity and type 2 diabetes.
title: Imprinted Grb10, encoding growth factor receptor bound protein 10, regulates fetal growth independently of the insulin-like growth factor type 1 receptor (Igf1r) and insulin receptor (Insr) genes

finding: rs4722389 was identified as a new GWAS signal for psychopathology, marking it as a novel variant associated with mood and psychotic disorders.
title: Multivariate GWAS of psychiatric disorders and their cardinal symptoms reveal two dimensions of cross-cutting genetic liabilities

finding: This SNP, located near AC003088.1, was a new discovery associated with psychiatric risks, highlighting genetic underpinnings of mental illness.
title: Multivariate GWAS of psychiatric disorders and their cardinal symptoms reveal two dimensions of cross-cutting genetic liabilities

finding: This SNP was discovered to be a novel risk variant associated with the gene ABCB1, indicating potential impacts on mechanisms underlying mental health.
title: Multivariate GWAS of psychiatric disorders and their cardinal symptoms reveal two dimensions of cross-cutting genetic liabilities

finding: Located on chromosome 7, rs1990042 was found to be a heterogeneous locus contributing to the genetic understanding of psychiatric disorders.
title: Multivariate GWAS of psychiatric disorders and their cardinal symptoms reveal two dimensions of cross-cutting genetic liabilities

finding: The polymorphism rs1476679 was located within a CTCF-mediated topologically associating domain (TAD) and was associated with increased disease risk in late-onset Alzheimer's disease. This association was linked to its impact on CTCF binding and chromatin topology.
title: Ctcf Haploinsufficiency Mediates Intron Retention in A Tissue-specific Manner

finding: The minority allele and genotype of rs6459797 were linked to lower MMSE scores, particularly in individuals with fewer years of formal education. This suggests that education may influence the impact of this SNP on cognitive function, with lower educational attainment exacerbating the effect of the AA genotype.
title: Human microRNA-153-3p targets specific neuronal genes and is associated with the risk of Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The effects of rs736940 on Aβ deposition were significantly modified by age and sex, showing that older individuals exhibited increased Aβ deposition, particularly among men. The presence of the 'A' allele appeared to confer a protective effect against Aβ deposition, further enhanced by formal education.
title: Human microRNA-153-3p targets specific neuronal genes and is associated with the risk of Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs13225710 was linked to colorectal cancer migration and invasion via its dual targeting of CFTR and CGN, as presented in the research by Zhang et al. in 2021. This finding underscored the role of miR-125b in enhancing aggressive cancer traits through the regulation of these targets.
title: Dual role of CASP8AP2/FLASH in regulating epithelial-to-mesenchymal (EMT) plasticity

finding: The SNP rs9648854 was found to be associated with the expression of CNTNAP2 specifically during the defendo stage of differentiation. This association indicated that the differential expression of CNTNAP2 was influenced by the allelic state of rs9648854 during this late stage of cell differentiation.
title: Single-cell RNA-sequencing of differentiating iPS cells reveals dynamic genetic effects on gene expression

finding: The SNP rs9690350 was located in the region of the PDGFA gene, which has been associated with pubertal onset. This finding highlighted the genetic influence on puberty, specifically in relation to the role of DNA methylation at the cg15030014 CpG site in the GET4 gene that showed a strong environmental influence. Thus, it indicated that rs9690350 may serve as a marker for understanding the genetic and environmental interplay affecting puberty timing.
title: DNA methylation sites in early adulthood characterised by pubertal timing and development: A twin study

finding: The missense variant rs1799805 in the ACHE gene was significantly associated with a lower number of cigarettes per day (CPD), revealing a complex interaction between acetylcholine metabolism and smoking behavior.
title: Gene-Gene interactions and pleiotropy in the brain nicotinic pathway associated with the heaviness and precocity of tobacco smoking among outpatients with multiple substance use disorders

finding: The SNP rs2107595 was associated with atherosclerosis as it was described in a relevant study by Prestel et al. (2019), where it mediated allele-specific transcriptional regulation of HDAC9 via E2F3 and Rb1. This regulation may have implications in the context of peripheral artery disease (PAD) due to its connection with the E2F3 gene, which was identified as key in the analysis of the plaque tissue in the current study.
title: Paired transcriptomic analyses of atheromatous and control vessels reveal novel autophagy and immunoregulatory genes in peripheral artery disease

finding: The variant rs1244070394 (chr7:117480621:T:C) was significantly better imputed using the CFGP reference panel compared to TOPMed due to its higher minor allele count (MAC) among CF patients (6) compared to TOPMed (3). This variant's presence in the CFGP indicates its relevance to cystic fibrosis despite being rare.
title: Leveraging TOPMed Imputation Server and Constructing a Cohort-Specific Imputation Reference Panel to Enhance Genotype Imputation among Cystic Fibrosis Patients

finding: The variant rs77284892 (chr7:117509047:G:T) was reported as a CF-causing variant (E60K) with a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 2.1e-3 in CFGP but only 1.1e-5 in TOPMed. It was classified as stop-gain and had a high CADD phred score of 38, making it among the top 0.016% most deleterious variants in the human genome, thus highlighting its functional importance in cystic fibrosis.
title: Leveraging TOPMed Imputation Server and Constructing a Cohort-Specific Imputation Reference Panel to Enhance Genotype Imputation among Cystic Fibrosis Patients

finding: For rs893051013 (chr7:117656113:C:T), the reduced CFGP reference panel showed a true R2 of 0.94 while TOPMed showed only 0.50, demonstrating that although TOPMed is larger in sample size, the CFGP panel performed better for this variant, indicating the necessity of cohort-specific reference panels for accurate imputation in CF studies.
title: Leveraging TOPMed Imputation Server and Constructing a Cohort-Specific Imputation Reference Panel to Enhance Genotype Imputation among Cystic Fibrosis Patients

finding: The rs713598 SNP in TAS2R38 was previously identified as a tag SNP for the supertaster genotype. This study confirmed a frequency of the 49A allele at 59% among individuals of European ancestry, which closely matched earlier reports of 55% among Caucasians. This finding contributed to the understanding of genetic variations that influence taste perception.
title: Bitter taste genetics and oral health in Canadian Longitudinal Study on Aging

finding: The SNP rs4730673 near the MDFIC gene was correlated with the significant GWAS signal for same-sex sexual behavior (rs10261857) and also showed a notable reduction in the likelihood of childlessness, indicating its role in reproductive patterns.
title: Genome-wide analysis identifies genetic effects on reproductive success and ongoing natural selection at the FADS locus

finding: While rs10261857 was highlighted as a significant signal for same-sex sexual behavior, it also illustrated a broader context in understanding reproductive success through its correlation with NEB-increasing alleles.
title: Genome-wide analysis identifies genetic effects on reproductive success and ongoing natural selection at the FADS locus

finding: Identified as consistently associated with Alzheimer’s disease in GWAS, this SNP demonstrated a significant association with the down-regulation of TAS2R41 and TAS2R60 genes. Additionally, it was correlated with the upregulation of EPHB6 and ADGRB3 proteins, which are important in neuronal signaling and may influence neurodegenerative processes.
title: Genomic Study of Taste Perception Genes in African Americans Reveals SNPs Linked to Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: Specifically noted for its consistent association with Alzheimer’s disease across several studies, this SNP was linked to the down-regulation of TAS2R41. It also showed significant correlations with the upregulation of EPHB6 and ADGRB3 proteins, highlighting its potential influence in Alzheimer’s pathology through modulation of key signaling pathways.
title: Genomic Study of Taste Perception Genes in African Americans Reveals SNPs Linked to Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: rs705379 was identified as having an expression-modulating effect on Paraoxonase 1 (PON1) based on luciferase reporter assays and statistical fine-mapping. BigRNA predicted a much stronger effect for this variant, consistent with the experimental results.
title: An RNA foundation model enables discovery of disease mechanisms and candidate therapeutics

finding: rs854571 was characterized as another known expression modulation variant for PON1, and BigRNA assigned a stronger and correct direction for this variant's effect on expression.
title: An RNA foundation model enables discovery of disease mechanisms and candidate therapeutics

finding: rs3735590 was also confirmed as an eQTL for PON1, with BigRNA predicting a stronger effect and correct direction of influence on expression.
title: An RNA foundation model enables discovery of disease mechanisms and candidate therapeutics

finding: The SNP rs4917014 was significantly associated with the risk of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This association indicated that alleles at this genetic variant within the IKZF1 gene were linked to variations in the expression of IKZF1 as well as affecting the expression of other genes located on different chromosomes, demonstrating its role as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL). This significant finding contributed to understanding how variations in the IKZF1 gene and its associated SNPs may have broader implications for autoimmunity.
title: Manipulation of alternative splicing of IKZF1 elicits distinct gene regulatory responses in T cells

finding: rs573901234 was associated with short sleep duration of less than 5 hours, with a p-value of 1.4×10^-8, located near gene JHDM1D-AS1. This was a significant finding related to sleep duration.
title: Automated Feature Extraction from Population Wearable Device Data Identified Novel Loci Associated with Sleep and Circadian Rhythms

finding: The SNP rs11760336 was identified as significant due to its location within the promoter region of the DNAH11 gene, which is associated with ciliary dyskinesia. This SNP was involved in the detection of allele-specific (AS) events, showing a consistent AS imbalance of DNA methylation that contrasts with AS expression and chromatin active states in the gene body. The findings suggested that this SNP likely alters gene expression directly, and it was recognized as one of the AS single nucleotide variants (SNVs) linked to known expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) from the GTEx database. Moreover, it was noted that some AS SNVs, including rs11760336, overlapped with known genome-wide association study (GWAS) variants, indicating a functional relevance to disease.
title: The EN-TEx resource of multi-tissue personal epigenomes & variant-impact models

finding: The SNP rs34291892, located in the FOXP2 gene on chromosome 7, was associated with neck or shoulder pain in the UK Biobank at a P-value of 2.38 x 10^-10. While it was significant initially, it was only weakly replicated in the GS:SFHS study (P = 0.0240).
title: A genome-wide association study finds genetic variants associated with neck or shoulder pain in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs143664050 was identified as having a negative effect on Testin (TES) expression specifically in CD14+ monocytes, while it showed negligible effects in erythroblasts. The alternative allele was correlated with a predicted loss of accessible regions in monocytes, which could account for the reduction in TES expression. The disruption of a binding site for the transcription factor SPI1, which is only expressed in myeloid cells like monocytes, explained the cell-type specificity of this eQTL's effect.
title: scooby: Modeling multi-modal genomic profiles from DNA sequence at single-cell resolution

finding: The SNP rs16147, located in the promoter region of the NPY gene, was identified as decreasing NPY expression. This reduction was correlated with enhanced anxiety traits in humans, indicating its significant role in anxiety disorders, particularly relevant in the context of major depressive disorder and PTSD.
title: Modulation of Temporoammonic-CA1 Synapses by Neuropeptide Y is Through Y1 Receptors

finding: The SNP rs1635852, located in the first intron of JAZF1, displayed significant enhancer activity dependent on the HNF1 motif. Deleting the HNF1 motif led to a significant decrease in activity (p = 0.016). Although no statistically significant allelic difference was observed between the reference (T) and alternate (C) alleles (p = 0.31), the activity was expected to be higher for the non-risk allele C. This was consistent with prior findings suggesting a role of PDX1 in regulatory activity at this locus.
title: Using a modular massively parallel reporter assay to discover context-specific regulatory grammars in type 2 diabetes

finding: The G894T (rs1799983) polymorphism in the nitric oxide synthase (NOS3) gene was found to be a susceptibility biomarker for obesity, reinforcing the connection between genetic variants and obesity-related traits.
title: Identification of biomarkers and pathways for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis using next generation sequencing data and bioinformatics analysis

finding: The NOS3 rs2070744 polymorphism was reported to be associated with risk for multiple sclerosis, supporting its role in neuroimmune interactions.
title: Identification of biomarkers and pathways for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis using next generation sequencing data and bioinformatics analysis

finding: The rs1800795 polymorphism in the Interleukin 6 gene was linked to conditions such as cardiovascular diseases based on a meta-analysis of numerous studies, suggesting a broader impact on metabolic disorders like NAFLD.
title: Bioinformatics analysis of differentially expressed genes in non alcoholic fatty liver disease using next generation sequencing data

finding: The SNP rs1799889, associated with the serpine1 (pai-1) 4g/5g insertion/deletion promoter polymorphism, was linked to pre-eclampsia in a systematic review and meta-analysis. This finding suggested a significant correlation between this genetic variant and the risk of developing pre-eclampsia, contributing valuable insights into the genetic factors influencing this condition.
title: PLSKO: a robust knockoff generator to control false discovery rate in omics variable selection

finding: The SNP rs6842, which codes for a synonymous variation (N147N) in the AGR2 gene, was identified in the NCBI dbSNP database with a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.3355. This finding was significant as it was the only SNP in the AGR2 gene with a relatively higher MAF compared to other SNPs, suggesting potential implications in cancer phenotypes associated with AGR2 gene expression.
title: Integrative analysis of genomic and transcriptomic alterations of AGR2 and AGR3 in cancer

finding: The SNP rs55900499, identified as a synonymous variation (D40D) in the AGR3 gene, was noted in the NCBI dbSNP database with a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.0505. Similar to rs6842, this SNP stood out for having a higher MAF compared to other SNPs in the AGR3 gene, indicating its potential relevance to the function of AGR3 in relation to cancer traits.
title: Integrative analysis of genomic and transcriptomic alterations of AGR2 and AGR3 in cancer

finding: The rs142852921 reference G insertion allele was associated with an increased risk of type 1 diabetes. It showed a significant match to active promoter motifs in thymocytes, influencing the gene expression of correlated genes such as SKAP2 and HOXA7, which are also relevant in T cell signaling and differentiation.
title: Thymocyte regulatory variant alters transcription factor binding and protects from type 1 diabetes in infants

finding: The deletion of tfoY in V. natriegens, associated with SNP rs24650, was carried out following established methods, enabling further study into the bacterium's antibacterial capabilities.
title: Engineering a customizable antibacterial T6SS-based platform in Vibrio natriegens

finding: This SNP was among the significant loci in the EUR GWAS, linked to the gene MAD1L1, with a p-value of 4.17×10⁻⁸. It also showed nominal replication with a beta of -0.0712 in MVP analysis.
title: Genomic Characterization of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder in a Large US Military Veteran Sample

finding: The R1537C variant (rs35364414), which corresponds to a mutation in the GLI3 gene, was identified as a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) present in the modern human population. This SNP was shown to exist with varying allele frequencies across different populations, being most prevalent in Europeans (3.7%-7.7%) and least in Africans (0.8%-2.1%). The A allele associated with the R1537C variant derived from Neanderthals and Denisovans suggests that the SNP was accommodated in the genetic background of both archaic and present-day humans. In silico analysis indicated that the R1537C variant could be deleterious, although it did not compromise protein stability. Furthermore, the impacts on gene regulation and skeletal morphology observed in genome-edited mice underline the significance of this variant in human anatomical diversification.
title: A Neanderthal/Denisovan GLI3 variant contributes to anatomical variations in mice

finding: The study observed that reovirus had a significant impact on the immune response pathways in the context of MSS colorectal cancer. The effective combination of reovirus with immune checkpoint inhibition was particularly noted in MSS CRC cell lines and the CT26 syngeneic mouse model, which carried the KRAS mutation. This finding suggested that rs12113219, associated with many immune response traits, could be relevant in understanding the enhanced anti-tumor activity in patients with MSS CRCs undergoing treatment, thus supporting its role as a promising target for future clinical trials.
title: Reovirus sensitizes microsatellite stable colorectal cancer to anti-PD-1 treatment via cross-talk in innate and adaptive immune systems

finding: SNP rs10265001 located on 7q34 was linked to schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, autism spectrum disorder, and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) with a meta-analysis p-value of 3.58 x 10^-8. Its associated region interacted with the promoters of nearby genes, influencing critical signaling pathways and brain development processes.
title: Genome wide meta-analysis identifies genomic relationships, novel loci, and pleiotropic mechanisms across eight psychiatric disorders

finding: The SNP rs11533993 in CDK6 was found to be associated with white blood cell count, showing a p-value of 1.55e-84 and a beta coefficient of -0.0799, contributing to the understanding of genetic risk factors for this phenotype.
title: Low generalizability of polygenic scores in African populations due to genetic and environmental diversity

finding: The SNP rs79197902 disrupted a transcription factor binding site (TFBS), specifically affecting the CTCF binding site. This disruption was linked to changes in local methylation levels at the associated CpGs, cg03916490 and cg18402987.
title: Genetic impacts on DNA methylation help elucidate regulatory genomic processes

finding: The study indicated that the SNP rs2013 had a significant finding in relation to the age of acquisition effects on mental rotation skills among individuals learning Nicaraguan sign language. It was found that the timing of language acquisition influenced cognitive abilities, which could be linked to PFS as described in the context of language comprehension. This SNP was associated with variations in language development outcomes, particularly in how it affected mental synthesis capabilities in children.
title: Novel Linguistic Evaluation of Prefrontal Synthesis (LEPS) test measures prefrontal synthesis acquisition in neurotypical children and predicts high-functioning versus low-functioning class assignment in individuals with autism

finding: The study indicated that the functional GRM3 Kozak sequence variant rs148754219 was associated with an increased risk of schizophrenia, alcohol dependence, and bipolar disorder. This finding provided insight into how genetic variations in GRM3 could contribute to cognitive deficits and neuropsychiatric disorders, particularly in the context of impaired cognitive function observed in these mental health conditions.
title: Activating mGlu3 metabotropic glutamate receptors rescues schizophrenia-like cognitive deficits through metaplastic adaptations within the hippocampus

finding: The non-synonymous SNP (G185V) was classified as deleterious/damaging. It was confirmed by PANTHER, SNPs & GO, PhD-SNP, SNAP, indicating a significant potential impact on ABCB1.
title: In Silico Screening and Analysis of SNPs in Human ABCB1 (MDR1) Gene

finding: This non-synonymous SNP (E566K) was also classified as deleterious/damaging, being confirmed by multiple prediction tools including PANTHER and SNPs & GO, highlighting its potential adverse effects.
title: In Silico Screening and Analysis of SNPs in Human ABCB1 (MDR1) Gene

finding: This non-synonymous SNP (A80E) was found to be deleterious according to PhD-SNP and SNAP, indicating possible damaging effects, although it was confirmed by fewer resources.
title: In Silico Screening and Analysis of SNPs in Human ABCB1 (MDR1) Gene

finding: The SNP rs9986945 was linked to the SDK1 locus, identified as a novel variant associated with hay fever and eczema.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of 350,000 Caucasians from the UK Biobank identifies novel loci for asthma, hay fever and eczema

finding: This intergenic SNP was associated with levels of androsterone sulfate and 4-androsten-3beta,17beta-diol disulfate. It connected to CYP3A5 and CYP3A7, implicating these cytochrome P450 enzymes in steroid metabolism.
title: Reconstructing the blood metabolome and genotype using long-range chromatin interactions

finding: The SNP rs856554 was associated with the total editing rate in human blood, with a significant p-value of 3.89e-8. This finding highlighted that rs856554 was located in a lincRNA gene, LOC730338. The association persisted even after accounting for blood cell composition, albeit at a lower significance. However, this SNP did not have a significant influence on the expression levels of ADAR or ADARB1.
title: Genome-wide analysis of consistently RNA edited sites in human blood reveals interactions with mRNA processing genes and suggests correlations with cell types and biological variables

finding: The SNP rs6967330[A] was identified as a causal variant for early childhood asthma with severe exacerbations. It was associated with stabilized expression of the CDHR3 protein at the cell surface, which is the receptor used by RV-C for particle uptake. This SNP was further linked to an increased risk for respiratory tract illness specifically with RV-C, distinguishing it from other viruses, thus highlighting its significance in the context of asthma and susceptibility to RV-C infections.
title: Rhinovirus C replication is associated with the endoplasmic reticulum and triggers cytopathic effects in an in vitro model of human airway epithelium

finding: The GRB10 rs1800504 polymorphism was reported to be associated with the risk of coronary heart disease in patients with type 2 diabetes, linking it indirectly to cardiac conditions.
title: The Identification of Key Genes and Biological Pathways in Cardiac Arrest by Integrated Bioinformatics and Next Generation Sequencing Data Analysis

finding: This SNP was noted as a proxy to sentinel SLE SNP rs11185603, and its deletion resulted in increased expression of IKZF1, indicating its regulatory significance.
title: Human follicular helper T cell promoter connectomes reveal novel genes and regulatory elements at SLE GWAS loci

finding: As a sentinel variant for SLE, this SNP influenced the expression regulation of IKZF1 associated with TFH cells, reinforcing its significance in SLE.
title: Human follicular helper T cell promoter connectomes reveal novel genes and regulatory elements at SLE GWAS loci

finding: The GRB10 SNP rs1800504 polymorphism was shown to be associated with the risk of coronary heart disease in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
title: Bioinformatics and next generation data analysis reveals the potential role of inflammation in sepsis and its associated complications

finding: The SNP rs3735018 showed an increase in effect size towards urban residents' cohorts, indicating it was influenced by environmental factors, particularly urbanization, in the analysis of LDL cholesterol.
title: Accounting for heterogeneity due to environmental sources in meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies

finding: The R38W variant of cytochrome c, originally reported as a low frequency SNP (rs11548791), demonstrated unexpected results. Despite the hypothesis that the Trp sidechain would block substrate access due to its larger van der Waals volume compared to Arg, peroxidase activity was actually increased to ~60 M^-1 s^-1. This indicated that the Arg38 sidechain may not control access to peroxidase substrates, or that the R38W variant alters peroxidase activity through a different mechanism.
title: Altered structure and dynamics of pathogenic cytochrome c variants correlate with increased apoptotic activity

finding: The rs6943555 SNP in the AUTS2 gene was positively associated with schizophrenia in male patients within a Turkish population. This finding related to the broader phenotype of schizophrenia, showcasing AUTS2's involvement in neurodevelopmental disorders.
title: AUTS2 expression within mammalian lineage: a predictor of neural networks involved in Autism Spectrum Disorders

finding: In the analysis of the WIBR3 cell line, it was found to be heterozygous for the rs3173615 variant (TMEM106B p.T185S), which has been previously reported as a modifier of frontotemporal dementia. This finding was significant as it provided insight into the potential role of the variant in neurodegenerative disease contexts.
title: iSCORE-PD: an isogenic stem cell collection to research Parkinson’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs12113099 was linked to Transforming Growth Factor-beta (TGF-β) roles in cancer immunity as described in the publication from Cancers 2020. This finding underscored its significance in cancer immunology, revealing correlations between the SNP's variation and modulation of immune responses in tumor environments.
title: Fluorescent Chiral Quantum Dots to Unveil Origin-Dependent Exosome Uptake and Cargo Release

finding: Exhibited opposing parental effects on the lymphocyte-neutrophil ratio and maternal effects on HDL cholesterol, implicating its association with type 2 diabetes-related traits and biomarker potential.
title: Parent-of-origin effects in the UK Biobank

finding: This SNP was associated with leg impedance (maternal p-value = 2.1 × 10^-8), indicating maternal expression linked to body fat and muscle mass, which aligned with previous findings on related phenotypes.
title: Parent-of-origin effects in the UK Biobank

finding: The variant rs1990621 located in the TMEM106B gene region was significantly associated with neuronal proportion (p=6.40×10−07). This association was replicated in an independent dataset and the significance increased in multi-tissue meta-analysis (p=9.42×10−09) and joint analysis (p=7.66×10−10). The minor allele G of rs1990621 was associated with increased neuronal proportion in aging groups with neurodegenerative disorders and cognitive normal elderly cohorts, but not in younger schizophrenia subjects.
title: The TMEM106B rs1990621 protective variant is also associated with increased neuronal proportion

finding: The variant rs1990622, which was previously identified as a protective variant in FTD cohorts, is in high LD (r2=0.98) with rs1990621. It reported associations with increased neuronal proportions in the context of neurodegenerative diseases, reiterating the potential protective role of TMEM106B variants.
title: The TMEM106B rs1990621 protective variant is also associated with increased neuronal proportion

finding: Included in the FDA5 PRS, rs62475261 is upstream of HIP1 (associated with BMI) and downstream of RHBDD2 (related to eosinophil counts). It was associated with higher values in children experiencing rapid weight gain.
title: Polygenic risk score based on weight gain trajectories is predictive of childhood obesity

finding: This SNP was the most significantly associated variant with the common executive function (cEF) factor, showing an effect size (β) of -0.012 and a p-value of 2.1e-26, indicating its relevance in fast synaptic transmission processes as an expression Quantitative Trait Loci (eQTL) in cerebellar tissue mapped to the EARLY gene EXOC4.
title: Genome-Wide Association Study of Over 427,000 Individuals Establishes Executive Functioning as a Neurocognitive Basis of Psychiatric Disorders Influenced by GABAergic Processes

finding: This variant was found in PON2 and was associated with cognitive performance, being significant independent of HDL and glucose factors, suggesting its influence on cognition linked to metabolic conditions.
title: Exome-wide analysis reveals role of LRP1 and additional novel loci in cognition

finding: The synonymous variant rs7780766 in PTPN18 was linked to episodic memory, reinforcing the critical role of this gene in cognitive pathways.
title: Exome-wide analysis reveals role of LRP1 and additional novel loci in cognition

finding: As previously indicated, rs3802842, along with rs3087967, highlighted the intricate genetic landscape at 11q23.1 impacting CRC risk through eQTL dynamics involving POU2AF2, COLCA1, and POU2AF3.
title: Genetic variation at 11q23.1 confers colorectal cancer risk by dysregulation of colonic tuft cell transcriptional activator POU2AF2

finding: The SNP rs12666575 was associated with schizophrenia susceptibility in a Chinese population. This finding indicated that the MAD1L1 gene polymorphism had a significant relationship to the etiology of schizophrenia, linking it to psychiatric disorders.
title: DPYSL2/CRMP2 isoform B knockout in human iPSC-derived glutamatergic neurons confirms its role in mTOR signaling and neurodevelopmental disorders

finding: The SNP rs871925 demonstrated an association with both prenatal famine exposure and schizophrenia in a Chinese population. This study reinforced the idea that genetic variants can interact with environmental factors like famine during critical developmental periods to influence the risk of developing schizophrenia.
title: DPYSL2/CRMP2 isoform B knockout in human iPSC-derived glutamatergic neurons confirms its role in mTOR signaling and neurodevelopmental disorders

finding: rs10274982 was located within the pseudogene AZGP1P1 and showed interactions with ZCWPW1. It was implicated in the regulation of lipid metabolism and associated with immune response pathways relevant to AD.
title: S-BEAM: A Semi-Supervised Ensemble Approach to Rank Potential Causal Variants and Their Target Genes in Microglia for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: This SNP showed contacts with FBXO24 and PCOLCE-AS1 in the ZCWPW1 locus, which is involved in crucial immune responses and AD pathology.
title: S-BEAM: A Semi-Supervised Ensemble Approach to Rank Potential Causal Variants and Their Target Genes in Microglia for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: Research indicated that the SNP rs13225638 was linked to the dysregulation of microtubule nucleating proteins in cancer cells. These proteins play a crucial role in maintaining proper chromosome alignment during mitosis, and their dysfunction contributed to CIN, corroborated by findings in the MCF10A breast cancer progression model.
title: A characterization of mitotic and centrosomal defects in a continuum model of Breast Cancer

finding: The missense variant rs1801368 in MAD1L1 was significantly associated with gains on chromosome 15, with a discovery p-value of 6.9 x 10^-23 and an odds ratio (OR) of 1.61 (1.46-1.77). This association was replicated in the UK population with p=5.1 x 10^-4 and a reduced effect size (OR=1.40), indicating that variations in MAD1L1 are crucial for proper chromosome segregation during mitosis, linked to clonal expansion.
title: The genomic landscape of clonal hematopoiesis in Japan

finding: Alterations in iron metabolism genes, including the rs7385804 SNP, were found to relate to sleep disorders in research done by Skonieczna-Żydecka et al. in 2020.
title: Comprehensive analysis of next-generation sequencing data in COVID-19 and its secondary complications

finding: The ABCB1 polymorphism rs1045642 impacted the efficacy and safety of amlodipine therapy in hypertensive patients, demonstrating its relevance in pharmacogenetics.
title: Identification of novel prognostic targets in acute kidney injury using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The CYP3A5 variant rs776746 was linked to the acetaminophen response in sepsis and septic shock, emphasizing its significance in critical care pharmacogenomics.
title: Identification of novel prognostic targets in acute kidney injury using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The finding related to rs2233580 was described in connection with the PAX4 gene, showing an odds ratio (OR) of 1.31 for the risk allele, highlighting its association with type 2 diabetes (T2D) in East Asian populations.
title: Identification of type 2 diabetes loci in 433,540 East Asian individuals

finding: Similar to rs2233580, rs3824004 was also linked to the PAX4 gene with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.23, reinforcing its role in T2D risk.
title: Identification of type 2 diabetes loci in 433,540 East Asian individuals

finding: rs78859629 was associated with Lactobacillus acidophilus and replicated, supporting earlier reports.
title: Inter-determination of blood metabolite levels and gut microbiome supported by Mendelian randomization

finding: The SNP rs7801723 was identified in a study by Medina-Gomez et al. as being strongly associated with skull bone mineral density (BMD). This association was located in the intronic region of the CPED1 gene, suggesting a link between variations in this region and craniofacial morphology.
title: Loss of cped1 does not affect bone and lean mass in zebrafish

finding: The SNP rs6950680 was found by Bonfante et al. in a GWA study focused on craniofacial morphology, where it was associated with 'jaw protrusion.' This variant was also located in the intronic region of the CPED1 gene, further supporting the influence of this gene on craniofacial traits.
title: Loss of cped1 does not affect bone and lean mass in zebrafish

finding: The SNP rs73147705 was identified in a trans-eQTL association with the gene RPL8, suggesting its involvement in immune cell regulatory networks.
title: Expression QTLs in single-cell sequencing data

finding: The study referenced by Lee and Kwon in 2020 reported that the O-GlcNAc transferase inhibitor, which affects O-GlcNAcylation, synergistically enhanced doxorubicin-induced apoptosis in HepG2 cells. This finding suggests that alterations in O-GlcNAc levels could play a significant role in modulating apoptosis in liver cancer cells, supporting the idea that O-GlcNAc regulation could enhance chemotherapeutic efficacy, making it relevant to etoposide's mechanism of action as described in the provided context.
title: Downregulation of O-GlcNAcylation enhances etoposide-induced p53-mediated apoptosis in HepG2 human liver cancer cells

finding: The SNP rs12705986 was located near the gene FOXP2, satisfying the criteria for linkage disequilibrium and inclusion in the fine-mapping credible set. This SNP fell within a peak specific to the inhibitory neuron subtype Inh-PDYN and was also associated with the peak of Inh-MEF2C, indicating its potential role in chronic pain pathways.
title: Spatial, transcriptomic and epigenomic analyses link dorsal horn neurons to chronic pain genetic predisposition

finding: The rs10488631 SNP, found in the IRF5 gene, also demonstrated a significant association with seropositivity in rheumatoid arthritis as reported by Vernerova et al. This association suggests that modifications at this locus could alter the immune system's function in RA, contributing to disease pathogenesis and management.
