title: Utilizing a PTPN22 gene signature to predict response to targeted therapies in rheumatoid arthritis

finding: The T allele of rs56980069 was associated with increased chromatin accessibility in progenitor cells, specifically linked to neuroticism. This SNP was shown to disrupt ZNF713 motifs, suggesting its influence in neuroticism susceptibility.
title: Cell-type specific effects of genetic variation on chromatin accessibility during human neuronal differentiation

finding: The finding related to rs4487645 indicated that FCNsignal successfully identified this SNP as a causal risk variant in myeloma.
title: Base-resolution prediction of transcription factor binding signals by a deep learning framework

finding: The rs2366739 SNP was identified as a functional variant involved in the transcriptional regulation of CD36, influencing platelet response to oxidized low-density lipoprotein (oxLDL) and associated with platelet count and platelet volume in GWAS studies. The study utilized a massively parallel reporter assay (MPRA) demonstrating significant transcription shifts and confirmed this finding through luciferase assays revealing that the 'C' allele was associated with lower levels of CD36 mRNA.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: Similar to rs2366739, rs1194196 was shown to affect CD36 transcriptional regulation in conjunction with rs2366739. The differential transcription response between the reference and alternate alleles was evidenced by multiple assays, including luciferase and EMSA. This SNP, located close to rs2366739 (<20 bp away), held clinical relevance, correlating with platelet count and volume as documented in GWAS.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: While rs6961069 was identified in previous GWAS studies as associated with platelet count and volume, it was also found to be a significant eQTL in MPRA analysis revealing differences in transcriptional regulation. This SNP contributed to the broader understanding of the genes regulating platelet traits.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: This SNP was associated with platelet traits such as volume and count in GWAS studies, similarly featured in the MPRA-assisted analysis, suggesting its role in regulating CD36 expression and its impact on platelet function.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: Associated with platelet count and volume in prior GWAS data, rs2177616 also formed part of the significant eQTL variants discovered in this comprehensive study, indicating its potential regulatory role in CD36 expression.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: Identified in GWAS studies for platelet parameters, rs11764390 was also confirmed as an eQTL variant affecting CD36 mRNA levels, highlighting its relevance in understanding genetic regulation of platelet function.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: This SNP was recognized as significant in the MPRA analysis with established effects on CD36 transcription, confirming its role in modulating platelet function based on prior association studies in platelet count and volume.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: Characterized as an influential variant in previous GWAS, rs1093831 also emerged as a relevant eQTL variant in the MPRA analysis, indicating its role in the regulation of CD36 expression.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: Associated with platelet traits in GWAS studies, the rs11464747 SNP was further confirmed as a variant influencing CD36 transcription levels in the MPRA findings.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: As an identified SNP in platelet-related GWAS, rs6467258 exhibited eQTL functionality, reinforcing its potential role in the regulation of CD36 expression on platelets.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: This SNP was linked to platelet function in GWAS studies and also demonstrated significant transcriptional differences in MPRA analysis, confirming its relevance in modulating CD36 expression.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: Identified in this study as significant for transcriptional regulation, rs819457 was associated with previous findings in GWAS studies linking it to platelet parameters.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: This SNP was recognized in the Bayesian analysis of the MPRA, contributing further insight into the genetic regulation of CD36 mRNA expression and associated platelet functions.
title: Identification of functional variants for platelet CD36 expression by Massively Parallel Reporter Assay

finding: The SNP rs1635852 was noted for its significant effects on islet chromatin accessibility and was subsequently shown to influence transcriptional activity, validating its role in T2D.
title: Functional characterization of thousands of type 2 diabetes-associated and chromatin-modulating variants under steady state and endoplasmic reticulum stress

finding: The SNP rs7783500 was determined to have significant transcriptional activation properties, contributing to its categorization as a putative causal SNP for T2D.
title: Functional characterization of thousands of type 2 diabetes-associated and chromatin-modulating variants under steady state and endoplasmic reticulum stress

finding: The intronic SNP rs111931861 in the gene KMT2E displayed a significant association with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), achieving genome-wide significance in a recent genome-wide association study (GWAS). The minor allele frequency (MAF) for this SNP was reported to be 0.034.
title: Local genetic correlation analysis reveals heterogeneous etiologic sharing of complex traits

finding: The mutation rs75039782 (C to T) in the 22nd intron of the CFTR gene generated a new donor GT splice-site associated with cystic fibrosis. Hexamer analysis indicated that this SNP produced a donor site with a stronger hexamer compared to the canonical donor site, which enabled the use of an otherwise unused upstream acceptor site, leading to the inclusion of a pseudo-exon containing a premature stop codon. This alteration created CFTR deficiency in affected individuals.
title: A basic framework governing splice-site choice in eukaryotes

finding: The SNP rs730437 in the EGFR gene was associated with susceptibility to Parkinson's disease (PD), indicating a genetic predisposition related to the EGFR signaling pathway which is implicated in dopamine neuron cell death.
title: UBL3 Interacts with Alpha-synuclein in Cells and the Interaction is Downregulated by the EGFR Pathway Inhibitor Osimertinib

finding: The SNP rs11506105 in the EGFR gene was also found to be associated with the susceptibility to Parkinson's disease (PD), suggesting that variations at this locus could influence the risk of developing the disease, particularly through pathways affecting alpha-synuclein pathology.
title: UBL3 Interacts with Alpha-synuclein in Cells and the Interaction is Downregulated by the EGFR Pathway Inhibitor Osimertinib

finding: This SNP, along with rs71559437, was identified as a top candidate impacting chromatin looping between several promoters, indicating its regulatory significance.
title: DSNetwork: An integrative approach to visualize predictions of variants’ deleteriousness

finding: The presence of this variant, in conjunction with rs6961094, was associated with chromatin interactions influencing gene regulation, confirming its role as a credible candidate.
title: DSNetwork: An integrative approach to visualize predictions of variants’ deleteriousness

finding: The study authored by Wiebringhaus et al. found that the SNP rs13236036 was associated with survival outcomes in prostate cancer. This finding highlighted the relevance of GP130 in the biological context of prostate cancer, particularly relating to tumor suppression and patient prognosis.
title: Cell-autonomous GP130 activation suppresses prostate cancer development via STAT3/ARF/p53-driven senescence and confers an immune-active tumor microenvironment

finding: The SNP rs10486567 was previously found to significantly associate with HIBADH expression in prostate tumor tissue and with TAX1BP1 expression in normal prostate tissue. This association was explained by the fact that both HIBADH, TAX1BP1, and the rs10486567 SNP are located within the same TAD, supported by Hi-C data indicating a large amount of contact across this genomic region.
title: epiTAD: a web application for visualizing high throughput chromosome conformation capture data in the context of genetic epidemiology

finding: This variant was identified as a homozygous variant at the PSV site chr7:5972749 when calling variants on PacBio CCS reads aligned with DuploMap. It was supported by 10X Genomics variant calls, in contrast to its absence in short-read calls.
title: Sensitive alignment using paralogous sequence variants improves long read mapping and variant calling in segmental duplications

finding: A heterozygous SNV located nearby at chr7:5972674 was also supported by 10X Genomics variant calls and identified in long-read variant calls. It was absent from short-read variant calls for the same individual.
title: Sensitive alignment using paralogous sequence variants improves long read mapping and variant calling in segmental duplications

finding: The SNP rs80338720 was identified in the gene SLC25A13 and associated with citrin deficiency, which had a carrier frequency of 3% (1 in 33) in the Vietnamese population, showing an allele frequency 2.4 times higher than in the East Asia population.
title: Genetic landscape of recessive diseases in the Vietnamese population from large-scale clinical exome sequencing

finding: This SNP was linked to co-expression QTLs affecting the ZFAND2A gene and was found to be involved in the heat-shock protein response, specifically at the 24h timepoint.
title: Single-cell RNA-sequencing reveals widespread personalized, context-specific gene expression regulation in immune cells

finding: The variant rs7795896 mapped to a ductal-specific distal cCRE which regulated CFTR expression. The T1D risk allele (C) reduced transcription factor binding and enhancer activity, leading to decreased CFTR expression in ductal cells. This variant was associated with increased risk of T1D as well as pancreatic diseases.
title: Large-scale genetic association and single cell accessible chromatin mapping defines cell type-specific mechanisms of type 1 diabetes risk

finding: The SNP rs12113437 was identified in the study by Subeha and Telleria (2020) discussing the anti-cancer properties of the HIV protease inhibitor nelfinavir (NFV). The finding highlighted that NFV effectively reduced the number and viability of high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC) cells, suggesting that genetic variations at this locus could influence response to NFV treatment.
title: Nelfinavir induces cytotoxicity towards high-grade serous ovarian cancer cells regardless of platinum sensitivity, involving induction of the unfolded protein response, modulation of protein synthesis, DNA damage, lysosomal impairment, and potentiation of toxicity caused by proteasome inhibition

finding: The SNP rs17855988, a missense variant in the elastin gene (ELN), was associated with facial aging. In the context of the study, elastin in the sclera was noted to be most dense around the optic nerve head, which is crucial for the characterization of the optic nerve head parameters like VCDR and VDD. The finding highlighted a potential link between the ELN gene and the biology of retinal ganglion cells, suggesting a possible avenue for drug repositioning. This SNP contributed to the systematic analysis that connected VCDR and glaucoma, providing new insights into the genetic underpinnings of these conditions.
title: Automated AI labelling of optic nerve head enables new insights into cross-ancestry glaucoma risk and genetic discovery in over 280,000 images from the UK Biobank and Canadian Longitudinal Study on Aging

finding: The A allele of the PGx variant rs1045642 in the ABCB1 gene was associated with a decreased fentanyl opioid dose requirement. This variant had a dominant mode of effect, where individuals with either the AA or GA genotype required a lower dosage compared to those with the GG genotype. The variant showed that 96.0% of the variation was partitioned within self-identified race/ethnicity (SIRE) groups, with individuals identifying as White being far more common carriers of the dosage-associated genotypes.
title: Population structure and pharmacogenomic risk stratification in the United States

finding: The PGx variant rs6977820 in the DPP gene was connected to an adverse response to antipsychotic medication, specifically associated with tardive dyskinesia in Schizophrenia patients. This variant had an additive effect mode, with the T allele positively correlated with African ancestry. A substantial majority of the variation (85.9%) was found within self-identified Black individuals, with a high odds ratio pointing to a significant risk of adverse reactions. Individuals identifying as Black had a 73.0% predictive accuracy for the risk-associated allele.
title: Population structure and pharmacogenomic risk stratification in the United States

finding: The missense variant rs1859788 (p.G78R) was identified as the lead cis-pQTL for Paired immunoglobulin-like type 2 receptor alpha (PILRA) in the Olink measure, showing a significant negative association (beta=-0.74, p<3.48x10-29) while also having positive associations with soluble isoforms using SOMAmer reagents. This variant was associated with protective effects against Alzheimer's disease.
title: Cross-platform proteomics to advance genetic prioritisation strategies

finding: The SNP rs7384878 had significant eQTLs in blood linked to several genes including PILRB, STAG3L5P, PMS2P1, GIGYF1, and EPHB4. The original study had annotated this SNP to the SPDYE3 gene.
title: snpXplorer: a web application to explore human SNP-associations and annotate SNP-sets

finding: The SNP rs13225810 was associated with metabolic plasticity in melanoma progression and response to targeted therapies, highlighting its relevance to treatment resistance in melanoma cells as described in the study by Alkaraki et al. (2021). This finding underscored the critical role of metabolic pathways in regulating the sensitivity of melanoma cells to therapy.
title: Ferroptosis susceptibility of melanoma cells: dependence on cell-type, acquired drug resistance, and medium composition

finding: The SNP rs13225599 was linked to the oncogenic KRAS signaling pathway, implicating its role in drug resistance concerning bladder cancer. This finding provided insights into the mechanisms of drug resistance that may complicate treatment strategies for patients suffering from bladder cancer related to schistosomiasis.
title: RNA-seq gene expression profiling of the bladder in a mouse model of urogenital schistosomiasis

finding: The lead variant rs11765305 at the EPHA1-AS1 locus was involved in the regulation of a long non-coding RNA associated with AD risk. The expression change regarding this SNP indicated its role in influencing AD risk through non-coding RNA interaction rather than through the adjacent gene EPHA1.
title: A map of transcriptional heterogeneity and regulatory variation in human microglia

finding: The SNP rs798502 was associated with more than 5 CpGs within the gene body of GNA12, suggesting its involvement in IBD-related pathways.
title: Methylation Quantitative Trait Loci are Largely Consistent across Disease States in Crohn’s disease

finding: The SNP rs1997243 was identified as the disease-causing variant in the locus 7p22, which was strongly associated with hypercholesterolemia. The risk allele of rs1997243 correlated with increased expression of GPR146 in humans. This variant was shown to increase promoter activity in luciferase reporter assays and was supported by eQTL analysis demonstrating a strong association between the rs1997243 G-allele and increased GPR146 expression in human samples.
title: Hypercholesterolemia risk associated GPR146 is an orphan G-protein coupled receptor that regulates blood cholesterol level in human and mouse

finding: The variant rs10254825 associated with the WNT16-CPED1 locus showed significant interaction with age for bone mineral density (BMD), with a vQTL p-value of 2.0×10^-45 and GEI p-value of 1.2×10^-7, highlighting its impact on BMD variation in relation to age.
title: Genotype-by-environment interactions inferred from genetic effects on phenotypic variability in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs2233580 exhibited significant associations with pancreatic cancer risk, aligning with known risk factors.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel GP2 gene risk variants for pancreatic cancer in the Japanese population

finding: The SNP rs4728092 was noted for its nominal significance relating to hemoglobin A1c levels, which ties into the risk factors of pancreatic cancer.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel GP2 gene risk variants for pancreatic cancer in the Japanese population

finding: In a previous study, the SNP rs2304376 was identified as an eQTL associated with the expression of the gene CHCHD2. Specifically, the A allele was consistently linked to lower expression levels of CHCHD2 compared to the G allele. This finding was replicated in the current study, where it was reported that the relationship remained robust across different culturing conditions, indicating that line-specific effects can be detected in both uni- and village cultures.
title: Village in a dish: a model system for population-scale hiPSC studies

finding: The SNP rs2108852 was examined for its association with the expression of the dynamic eGene RARRES2. The study supported previous findings, showing that the alternative C allele was correlated with higher RARRES2 expression in the pluripotent quintile (Q1) of hiPSCs. It was further noted that this expression effect diminished across sequential quintiles, corroborating the dynamic nature of the eQTL.
title: Village in a dish: a model system for population-scale hiPSC studies

finding: SNP rs2108851, which is in high linkage disequilibrium (R2 = 0.86) with rs11766288, exhibited the same associated allelic direction as previous eQTL findings in hiPSCs. This aligns with previous data that show that its genetic influence on expression can be discerned within hiPSC lines cultured in village systems, indicating consistent line-dependent transcriptional effects.
title: Village in a dish: a model system for population-scale hiPSC studies

finding: The SNP rs11766288 was previously implicated as an eQTL in hiPSCs, with results consistent with the findings of rs2108851, which is in linkage disequilibrium with it. The study reaffirmed that this SNP’s expression effect could be reliably identified in the contexts of village culture systems.
title: Village in a dish: a model system for population-scale hiPSC studies

finding: At the SNRPC locus, the original paper indicated that MARC0061142 was the most significant SNP associated with backfat thickness (P-value = 5.42 × 10^-8). The new finding identified the chr7:30719820:G:A SNP as more significant, also showing a tight linkage (r² = 0.99), suggesting it might be a potential causal variant.
title: PHARP: A pig haplotype reference panel for genotype imputation

finding: At the GRM4 locus, the study found a missense variant chr7:30191165:T:C that was associated with backfat thickness. It exhibited a P-value of 1.19 × 10^-7 and had a strong linkage (r² = 0.98) with its most significant SNP.
title: PHARP: A pig haplotype reference panel for genotype imputation

finding: Another finding concerned the PACSIN1 locus, where the missense variant chr7:30509485:C:G was linked to backfat thickness. It had a P-value of 8.91 × 10^-8 and a high linkage (r² = 0.98) with the most significant SNP.
title: PHARP: A pig haplotype reference panel for genotype imputation

finding: At the PACSIN1 locus, this missense variant, chr7:30509543:C:G, was also found to be associated with backfat thickness, with a P-value of 8.91 × 10^-8 and a linkage (r² = 0.98) to its most significant SNP.
title: PHARP: A pig haplotype reference panel for genotype imputation

finding: The chr7:30250983:G:C SNP at the PACSIN1 locus was identified in relation to backfat thickness, with a reported P-value of 6.08 × 10^-8, contributing to the significance of the association.
title: PHARP: A pig haplotype reference panel for genotype imputation

finding: Lastly, the chr7:30497108:T:C SNP was found at the PACSIN1 locus and related to backfat thickness. Its P-value was 1.44 × 10^-8, indicating a significant association and a high linkage with relevant loci.
title: PHARP: A pig haplotype reference panel for genotype imputation
